- [ ] Price approaching re-entry into consolidation zone

C. ENTRY EXECUTION

- [ ] Price at consolidation boundary ready to re-enter
- [ ] Confirm candle breaks consolidation body (not wick)
- [ ] Confirm candle will CLOSE above/below consolidation (for entry confirmation)
- [ ] Direction aligns with primary trend (long for uptrend, short for downtrend)
- [ ] Stop loss calculated: below consolidation for longs, above for shorts
- [ ] Risk amount determined: entry price - stop loss = pips risked
- [ ] Position size calculated: (account size x 1-2%) / pips risked = shares
- [ ] Entry order ready: limit order at consolidation level
- [ ] Take profit 1 set: entry + (2 x risk) for 1:2 RR
- [ ] Take profit 2 set: next major structure or trail stop ready
- [ ] Orders placed: entry, SL, TP1, TP2 all active

D. POST-TRADE REVIEW

- [ ] Trade outcome: win, loss, or breakeven
- [ ] Trend assessment: did primary trend continue as expected?
- [ ] Fake out validity: was consolidation re-entry genuine?
- [ ] Entry quality: was break/close confirmed or premature?
- [ ] Stop loss hit: if yes, fake out was false reversal
- [ ] Take profit hit: if yes, market continued as expected
- [ ] R-multiple: (exit - entry) / (entry - stop loss)
- [ ] Emotional discipline: any deviations from plan?
- [ ] Consolidation quality: was it obvious or ambiguous?
- [ ] Trend clarity: was primary trend unmistakable?
- [ ] Improvement notes: what worked, what to adjust?
- [ ] Trade logged: full details recorded


Episode 7: How to Draw Support and Resistance Levels Like a Professional



00:00 - 00:56 | Introduction & Core Objective

Smart money traders identify support/resistance exactly like experts. Learning these techniques is everything needed to spot high-probability institutional reference levels. Promise: advanced techniques to spot S&R levels like professionals.

ICT Mapping:
- Support/Resistance = institutional order placement reference zones
- Expert identification = understanding where smart money places orders
- S&R levels = where institutional traders accumulate/distribute
- Key levels attract institutions to take action

00:56 - 02:50 | Foundational Concepts: What Are Support & Resistance?

EXACT DEFINITION:
- Support & Resistance = zones where price has previously reacted
- May potentially react again in future
- Historical reaction = future reaction likelihood indicator

WHY IDENTIFY THESE LEVELS:
- Serve as potential entry or exit points
- When price reaches previous S/R level, price will:
  * Option 1: Bounce back away from level
  * Option 2: Violate level and continue in prior direction until next S/R
- Must be drawn in chart as reminder to look

CRITICAL PRINCIPLE:
- Always wait for price action confirmation
- Never trade S/R blindly, regardless of level quality
- Confirmation signals required before entry

ICT Mapping:
- Support/Resistance = institutional reference levels
- Price reaction = smart money taking positions
- Entry/Exit points = where institutions manage orders

02:50 - 06:32 | Six Criteria for Quality Support & Resistance

CRITERION 1: SWING HIGHS & LOWS
- Highest and lowest points price recently hit
- Swing high = resistance (price reversed down)
- Swing low = support (price reversed up)

CRITERION 2: MULTIPLE REJECTIONS
- More rejections = better level
- Each rejection = traders taking action at that level
- Significance: confirms level importance across time periods

CRITERION 3: LEVEL SHOULD BE OBVIOUS
- When you look at chart, identify level immediately
- Obvious = more traders watching = higher activity
- Significance: obvious levels attract more institutional orders

CRITERION 4: DRASTIC BOUNCE
- Not tiny move, but SHARP reversal
- Price bounces decisively away from level
- Big candles indicate institutional rejection

CRITERION 5: BOTH SUPPORT & RESISTANCE
- Level provided support multiple times
- Then level broke, became resistance
- Then level provided resistance again
- Shows zone strength across market cycles

CRITERION 6: RECENTLY FORMED/RESPECTED
- Latest S&R levels = priority
- Recent rejections more effective than old ones
- Current time period validation = higher probability

INTEGRATION NOTE:
- Only need ONE criterion to qualify level
- More criteria met = higher probability zone
- More = better principle applies here

ICT Mapping:
- Multiple rejections = institutional zone confirmation
- Obvious levels = smart money reference points
- Drastic bounces = institutional order accumulation
- Recent rejections = current institutional interest

06:32 - 16:48 | Detailed Chart Examples & Criteria Application

EXAMPLE 1: NCD/USD CHART - Identifying Multiple Criteria

Top Resistance Level Analysis:
- Meets criterion 1: Swing high (highest recent point)
- Meets criterion 2: Multiple rejections (3 rejections visible)
- Meets criterion 3: Obvious level (instantly identifiable)
- Meets criterion 4: Drastic movement (sharp bounce)
- Result: High-quality resistance level

Second Level - 6 Rejections:
- Criterion 2: Six rejections (powerful confirmation)
- Criterion 5: Provided both support and resistance
- Criterion 6: Recently respected in current period
- Result: Premium quality zone (multiple strong criteria)

Third Level - Support Zone:
- Criterion 1: Swing low (lowest recent point)
- Criterion 2: Four rejections
- Criterion 4: Drastic movement (sharp bounce)
- Criterion 6: Recently respected
- Result: High-quality support level

EXAMPLE 2: EURO/DOLLAR CHART

Top Resistance:
- Criterion 1: Swing high
- Criterion 4: Drastic movement

Second Level:
- Criterion 4: Drastic movement
- Criterion 3: Obvious

Third Level:
- Criterion 4: Drastic movement
- Criterion 3: Obvious

Fourth Level (Key Zone):
- Criterion 2: Multiple rejections
- Criterion 5: Both support and resistance
- Criterion 4: Drastic movement
- Criterion 3: Obvious
- Result: Most criteria met = highest probability zone

Fifth Level (Support):
- Criterion 1: Swing low
- Criterion 2: Rejections
- Criterion 3: Obvious
- Criterion 6: Recently respected

CHART CLEANLINESS PRINCIPLE:
- Identify all key levels
- Create clean, uncluttered view
- Only mark obvious, high-probability zones
- Avoid minor levels that clutter analysis

16:48 - 19:34 | Lines vs. Zones & Professional Drawing Methods

QUESTION: LINES OR ZONES?

Method 1: Single Solid Line
- Pros: Simple, single line touches all reversals
- Cons: Works if line perfectly aligned
- Use: When alignment is perfect

Method 2: Multiple Lines (Candle Closes)
- One line per candle close touching level
- Pros: Precise touches at each reversal
- Cons: Chart becomes messy
- Problem: Confusion increases with complexity

Method 3: Zones (PREFERRED PROFESSIONAL METHOD)
- Draw rectangular zone containing most touches
- Pros: Clean chart, clear area, professional appearance
- Contains both closes and wicks
- Makes sense for all timeframes
- Prevents confusion

PRO TIP: SIZING ZONES CORRECTLY
- Don't draw massive zones covering everything
- Draw smaller zones containing most touches
- Covers candle bodies, wicks, reversal points
- Avoids confusion from oversized areas
- Watches can be added without chart getting worse

KEY PRINCIPLE: PRICE ACTION > EXACT LINE
- No difference whether lines or zones (both = S&R areas)
- Always wait for price action to place trade
- Trade in general area, not at solid price point
- Zones allow for flexible entry within area

EXAMPLE: US DOLLAR CURRENCY INDEX

Top Zone:
- Swing high level
- Zone includes most candle closes and wicks

Middle Zone:
- Rejections visible
- Professional zone drawn

Support Zone:
- Swing low level
- Professional zone drawn

Result: Clean chart with key levels only

ICT INTEGRATION:
- Zones = institutional reference areas
- Exact lines unnecessary for entry
- Price action entry > exact price level
- Professional zones match institutional thinking

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- Support and Resistance are zones where price has previously reacted and may react again; they serve as potential entry/exit points.

- Six criteria for quality S&R: swing highs/lows, multiple rejections, obvious levels, drastic bounces, both support and resistance, recently formed/respected.

- Only one criterion needed to identify S&R level; more criteria met = higher probability zone; more is always better.

- Swing highs and lows are highest/lowest recent prices; drastic bounces mean sharp reversals with big candles after touching level.

- Multiple rejections indicate traders have taken action at level multiple times; levels respected on both sides show zone strength across cycles.

- Obvious levels attract more traders and institutions; recent S&R levels take priority over historical levels; latest rejections are more effective.

- Professional method: draw zones, not single lines; zones contain most candle closes and wicks while keeping chart clean and uncluttered.

- Never draw massive zones covering everything; draw smaller zones containing key touches; prevents confusion as timeframes increase.

- Price action entry matters more than exact line; trade in general S&R area, not at solid price point; zones allow flexible entry within area.

- Fake breakouts occur when price breaks zone then reverses; distinguish genuine breakouts from fakeouts using price action confirmation after zone break.

PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: Scan chart for swing highs (highest recent points) and swing lows (lowest recent points).
STEP 2: Mark each swing point as potential resistance (high) or support (low).
STEP 3: Verify each level meets at least one criterion (ideally multiple).
STEP 4: Count rejections at each level (more = better confirmation).
STEP 5: Confirm level is obvious (identifiable immediately on chart).
STEP 6: Verify price bounced drastically from level (big candles, sharp movement).
STEP 7: Check if level provided both support and resistance (respected by both sides).
STEP 8: Prioritize recent levels over historical levels from chart.
STEP 9: Combine criteria: highest-probability zones meet 3+ criteria.
STEP 10: Draw zones (not lines) to contain most touches, keep chart clean.
STEP 11: Zone sizing: include key touches without oversizing (prevents confusion).
STEP 12: Place entries in general zone area, not at exact price line.
STEP 13: Wait for price action confirmation before entering trade at S&R.

================================================================================
TRADING CHECKLISTS
================================================================================

A. SUPPORT/RESISTANCE IDENTIFICATION

- [ ] Swing highs identified: marked as potential resistance
- [ ] Swing lows identified: marked as potential support
- [ ] At least one criterion met per level (one minimum required)
- [ ] Multiple rejections counted at each level (if applicable)
- [ ] Obvious levels prioritized: identifiable within seconds
- [ ] Drastic bounces confirmed: big candles, sharp reversal
- [ ] Both S&R function checked: level respected on both sides
- [ ] Recency verified: prioritize recent levels over old ones
- [ ] Level confidence assessed: 1-3 criteria (low), 4-5 (medium), 6 (high)
- [ ] Key levels isolated: only mark obvious high-probability zones

B. ZONE DRAWING METHODOLOGY

- [ ] Chart cleanliness priority: only essential levels drawn
- [ ] Zone format chosen: zones preferred over lines
- [ ] Zone size appropriate: contains key touches without oversizing
- [ ] Candle closes included: most touches in zone
- [ ] Wicks included: zone contains relevant wicks
- [ ] Minor levels excluded: focus only on obvious key levels
- [ ] Professional appearance: clean, uncluttered chart
- [ ] Timeframe scalability: zone approach works across timeframes
- [ ] Area vs. exact price: trades placed in general area, not exact line
- [ ] Fake breakout identified: breaks through zone then reverses (noted for later)

C. ENTRY PREPARATION AT S&R LEVELS

- [ ] Support/Resistance identified and marked
- [ ] Multiple criteria verified (higher criteria = better setup)
- [ ] Zone drawn cleanly and appropriately sized
- [ ] Price approaching S&R level: monitored for entry
- [ ] Price action signals watched: entry confirmation patterns ready
- [ ] Entry confirmation required: never blind entry at S&R alone
- [ ] Candlestick patterns identified: engulfing, rejection patterns
- [ ] Momentum confirmed: entries backed by strong momentum
- [ ] Entry order ready: within zone area, not exact price
- [ ] Stop loss positioned: beyond S&R zone extreme

D. POST-TRADE ANALYSIS

- [ ] Trade taken or skipped: reason documented
- [ ] S&R level respected: did price bounce or break through?
- [ ] Zone effectiveness: did entry area work as expected?
- [ ] Price action confirmation: did pattern work as analyzed?
- [ ] Result: Win, loss, or breakeven
- [ ] Level quality assessment: which criteria were valid?
- [ ] Fake breakout recognized: if applicable
- [ ] Chart accuracy: were zones drawn correctly?
- [ ] Timeframe context: did higher TF align with setup?
- [ ] Improvement notes: what to adjust next time?


Episode 8: What Are the Best Pairs to Trade in Forex? (Sessions & Correlation)


00:00 - 00:42 | Introduction & Core Questions

In Forex market, three major sessions exist. Key questions: Which currency pairs work best in each session? Which pairs have more liquidity? How are currencies correlated across different sessions? Promise: explain crucial answers needed to succeed in trading career.

ICT Mapping:
- Sessions = institutional trading windows
- Liquidity = smart money activity concentration
- Correlation = understanding which currencies move together
- Session-specific pairs = aligning with institutional flow

00:42 - 01:09 | Seven Major Currency Pairs

Major currency pairs are most actively traded pairs in the world, making them relatively low spread compared to minor pairs. Because of low spread, traders have more interest trading these pairs. Also, three major sessions exist in market.

ICT Mapping:
- Major pairs = highest institutional volume
- Low spread = tighter pricing, better fills
- Active trading = liquidity clustering

01:09 - 02:32 | Asian Session: Currency Activity & Correlation

ASIAN SESSION ACTIVE CURRENCIES:
- Japanese Yen (JPY)
- Australian Dollar (AUD)
- New Zealand Dollar (NZD)
- Gold (some movements)

LIQUIDITY PRINCIPLE:
- Understanding which pairs have more liquidity = easier to trade in sessions
- Example question: Should someone trade GBP/USD (Pound/Dollar) in Asian session?
- Answer: NO - British Pound and US Dollar trades extremely limited in Asian session
- Result: No liquidity in movements traders want to see when placing trades
- Key: Look at pairs being actively traded in these sessions

CORRELATION IN ASIAN SESSION:
- USD/JPY, EUR/JPY, GBP/JPY all move in SAME direction during Asian session
- Reason: In all these pairs, only YEN is currency actively traded in Asian session
- Their movement influenced by Yen ONLY

AUD/JPY EXCEPTION:
- May NOT move same as other three during Asian session
- Reason: BOTH AUD and JPY actively traded
- Now you have fight between TWO currencies

TRADING PRINCIPLE FOR ASIAN SESSION:
- Choose pair influenced by only ONE active currency in that session
- Examples: GBP/JPY, EUR/JPY, USD/JPY in Asian session
- These pairs = cleaner directional moves

ICT Mapping:
- Asian session = YEN dominance window
- Single-currency influence = cleaner institutional flow
- Dual-currency pairs (AUD/JPY) = conflicting order flow
- Session alignment = trading with dominant institutions

02:32 - 03:30 | London Session: Currency Activity & Strength/Weakness

LONDON SESSION ACTIVE CURRENCIES:
- British Pound (GBP)
- Euro (EUR)
- Swiss Franc (CHF)
- Gold

SAME CONCEPT APPLIES:
- Session-specific liquidity matters
- Pair selection based on active currencies

STRENGTH VS. WEAKNESS PRINCIPLE:
- Example: Trading EUR/GBP in London session
- Must ensure ONE pair is WEAK and another is STRONG
- This is ONLY way EUR/GBP will move
- If BOTH currencies strong = high chance market will consolidate and be hard to trade

ICT Mapping:
- London session = EUR/GBP dominance window
- Strength differential = directional clarity for institutions
- Consolidation = conflicting institutional interest
- Relative strength = key to trending moves

03:30 - 04:48 | New York Session & Recap of Core Questions

NEW YORK SESSION ACTIVE CURRENCIES:
- US Dollar (USD)
- Canadian Dollar (CAD)
- British Pound (GBP)
- Euro (EUR)
- Swiss Franc (CHF)
- Gold

RECAP: ANSWERING THE THREE CORE QUESTIONS

Question 1: What currency pairs work best?
Answer: Pairs with lot of liquidity in ONE direction in sessions. Example: GBP/JPY has lot of liquidity in London and New York sessions AND influenced by Pound only.

Question 2: Which pairs have more liquidity?
Answer: Pairs being actively traded in specific sessions. Session-specific activity = liquidity concentration.

Question 3: How are currencies correlated in different sessions?
Answer: Correlation depends on currencies being actively traded in sessions. Example: GBP/JPY and USD/JPY highly correlated in Asian sessions because Yen actively traded, so Yen influences their movements.

ICT Mapping:
- New York session = USD dominance window
- Single-currency influence (GBP/JPY in NY) = aligned with institutional flow
- Correlation = institutional order clustering
- Session overlap = highest liquidity windows

04:48 - 04:57 | Closing Remarks

Summary: Understanding session-specific pairs, liquidity concentration, and correlation = crucial for trading success. Choose pairs aligned with active session currencies for cleaner moves.

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- Forex market has three major sessions: Asian, London, and New York; each session has specific currencies being actively traded.

- Major currency pairs have lower spreads than minor pairs due to higher trading activity; traders prefer these for better execution.

- Asian session: Japanese Yen, Australian Dollar, New Zealand Dollar, and Gold are actively traded; avoid GBP/USD and other non-Asian pairs.

- Correlation in Asian session: USD/JPY, EUR/JPY, GBP/JPY move in same direction because only Yen is actively traded in all three pairs.

- AUD/JPY exception: may not correlate with other Yen pairs because both AUD and JPY are actively traded, creating conflicting forces.

- Trading principle: choose pairs influenced by only ONE active currency in that session for cleaner directional moves and better entries.

- London session: Pound, Euro, Swiss Franc, and Gold actively traded; same session-specific principles apply for pair selection.

- Strength vs. weakness: for pairs like EUR/GBP in London, one currency must be strong and other weak; both strong = consolidation and hard to trade.

- New York session: US Dollar, Canadian Dollar, Pound, Euro, Swiss Franc, and Gold actively traded; highest liquidity during overlaps.

- Best pairs to trade: those with high liquidity in one direction during specific sessions; example is GBP/JPY in London/New York influenced by Pound only.



PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS

STEP 1: Identify current trading session (Asian, London, or New York).
STEP 2: List currencies actively traded in that session.
STEP 3: Select pairs where only ONE currency is actively traded in session.
STEP 4: Avoid pairs where BOTH currencies are actively traded (conflicting forces).
STEP 5: Check correlation: pairs sharing same active currency move together.
STEP 6: For London session pairs (EUR/GBP), confirm one currency strong, other weak.
STEP 7: Prioritize major pairs with low spreads for better execution.
STEP 8: Align trade direction with active currency's strength/weakness.
STEP 9: Monitor session overlaps for highest liquidity windows.
STEP 10: Avoid trading pairs outside their active sessions (low liquidity).
STEP 11: Use session-specific pairs for cleaner price action and setups.
STEP 12: Journal session-specific results to refine pair selection over time.

================================================================================
TRADING CHECKLISTS
================================================================================

A. SESSION IDENTIFICATION & PAIR SELECTION

- [ ] Current session identified: Asian, London, or New York
- [ ] Active currencies in session listed
- [ ] Pairs with ONE active currency prioritized
- [ ] Pairs with TWO active currencies avoided (conflicting forces)
- [ ] Major pairs selected (lower spreads)
- [ ] Session overlap checked (highest liquidity)
- [ ] Pair liquidity confirmed for current session
- [ ] Avoid non-active pairs (e.g., GBP/USD in Asian)
- [ ] Correlation understood (shared currency = same direction)
- [ ] Session-specific strategy adjusted

B. ASIAN SESSION TRADING

- [ ] Japanese Yen (JPY) is primary active currency
- [ ] AUD, NZD also active (but create conflicts with JPY)
- [ ] USD/JPY, EUR/JPY, GBP/JPY prioritized (Yen-only influence)
- [ ] AUD/JPY avoided (dual-currency conflict)
- [ ] Gold considered (some movement in Asian session)
- [ ] GBP/USD, EUR/USD avoided (no liquidity)
- [ ] Yen pairs expected to correlate (move same direction)
- [ ] Price action confirmation required before entry
- [ ] Low liquidity pairs skipped
- [ ] Session timing respected (Asian hours only)

C. LONDON SESSION TRADING

- [ ] GBP, EUR, CHF are primary active currencies
- [ ] Gold actively traded
- [ ] EUR/GBP requires strength differential (one strong, one weak)
- [ ] Both strong = consolidation expected, avoid trade
- [ ] GBP/JPY good choice (Pound-only influence in London)
- [ ] EUR/JPY good choice (Euro-only influence in London)
- [ ] Pairs with clear strength/weakness selected
- [ ] Session overlap with New York monitored (highest liquidity)
- [ ] Price action confirmation before entry
- [ ] Avoid consolidating pairs (both currencies strong/weak)

D. NEW YORK SESSION TRADING

- [ ] USD, CAD, GBP, EUR, CHF actively traded
- [ ] Gold actively traded
- [ ] GBP/JPY prioritized (Pound-only influence, high liquidity)
- [ ] USD pairs have high activity
- [ ] EUR/USD, GBP/USD good choices (USD active)
- [ ] Session overlap with London = highest liquidity window
- [ ] Correlation checked (USD pairs may move together)
- [ ] Price action confirmation before entry
- [ ] Major news events monitored (USD-sensitive)
- [ ] Risk management adjusted for higher volatility


Episode 9: Simple 1 Minute Smart Money Trading Strategy


00:00 - 00:56 | Introduction & Strategy Overview

Advanced 1-minute scalping strategy based on smart money concepts. Accurate and profitable approach to elevate trading to next level. No indicators as entry signals; RSI used as confirmation tool only. Promise: detailed explanation with live trade examples.

ICT Mapping:
- Scalping = institutional micro-flow execution
- 1-minute timeframe = capturing institutional order fills
- Smart money concepts = aligning with institutional structure
- Price action entry = order block identification

00:56 - 02:14 | Strategy Prerequisites & Order Block Definition

Five critical topics required:
1. Order Block (OB) - institutional liquidity zones from large money entering market
2. Break of Structure (BOS) - trend continuation signal
3. Change of Character (CHOCH) - trend reversal signal
4. RSI Divergence - momentum shift confirmation
5. Confluence validation - aligning multiple confirmations

Order Block Definition:
Supply and demand zones formed when institutional money enters market. Bullish OB = last bearish candle before bullish move. Bearish OB = last bullish candle before bearish move.

ICT Mapping:
- Order blocks = institutional order clustering
- Imbalance = smart money positioning
- Last candle before move = institutional entry point

02:14 - 03:37 | Break of Structure & Change of Character

Break of Structure (BOS):
- Signals trend CONTINUATION
- Shadow break acceptable
- Example: uptrend BOS = break above recent high

Change of Character (CHOCH):
- Signals trend REVERSAL
- Requires CLOSE beyond structural level (stricter than BOS)
- Example: uptrend CHOCH = close below recent low
- Key difference: CHOCH requires candle close, not just shadow

ICT Mapping:
- BOS = institutional momentum continuation
- CHOCH = institutional direction shift
- Structural levels = institutional reference points

03:37 - 05:37 | RSI Indicator & Divergence Signals

RSI Basics:
Momentum indicator measuring speed and magnitude of price changes. Evaluates overbought (70) and oversold (30) conditions.

Bearish Divergence:
- Price makes HIGHER HIGHS
- RSI makes LOWER HIGHS
- Signals rising bearish momentum
- Entry: short position when RSI crosses below 70

Bullish Divergence:
- Price makes LOWER LOWS
- RSI makes HIGHER LOWS
- Signals rising bullish momentum
- Entry: long position when RSI crosses above 30

ICT Mapping:
- Overbought 70 = institutional distribution
- Oversold 30 = institutional accumulation
- Divergence = momentum shift before price shift
- Indicators confirm institutional flow

05:37 - 06:38 | Four-Step Scalping Strategy

Step 1: Analyze 15-minute timeframe; identify market structure; mark institutional order blocks; wait for price to reach 15-min OB

Step 2: Switch to 1-minute timeframe; wait for Change of Character within 15-min OB; identify new 1-minute order blocks generated by CHOCH movement

Step 3: Add RSI to 1-minute chart; look for divergence signals; confirm divergence aligns with intended entry direction (bullish divergence for longs, bearish for shorts)

Step 4: Place trade few pips above/below 1-min OB; set stop loss at OB extreme; take profit 1 at 1:2 reward:risk ratio (close 50%); take profit 2 at next major structure or trailing stop

ICT Mapping:
- Step 1 = macro institutional structure identification
- Step 2 = micro order block recognition
- Step 3 = momentum confirmation
- Step 4 = entry aligned with institutional flow

06:38 - 12:50 | Live Example 1: EUR/USD Bullish Trade

15-Minute Setup:
- Uptrend established (higher highs and higher lows)
- Order block identified in accumulation zone

1-Minute Entry Sequence:
- Price enters 15-min OB zone
- Strong downtrend visible on 1-minute
- Change of Character forms (price closes above recent higher low)
- New 1-minute order block generated from CHOCH movement

RSI Confirmation:
- Points A and B: price makes LOWER LOWS
- Points A and B: RSI makes HIGHER LOWS
- Bullish divergence confirmed

Execution:
- Entry: few pips above 1-min OB
- Stop loss: few pips below OB extreme (approximately 5 pips)
- TP1: 50% position at 1:2 ratio (breakeven protection)
- TP2: trail stop or next major 15-min structure

Multiple Entries Cascade:
- Price forms new Break of Structure = new order block
- Second order placed with HALF position size
- Third order placed following same logic
- Max 3 open positions maintained
- Result: multiple profitable entries captured

ICT Mapping:
- 15-min OB = macro institutional liquidity zone
- 1-min CHOCH = micro momentum confirmation
- RSI divergence = institutional momentum alignment
- Multiple OBs = cascading institutional orders

12:50 - 15:31 | Live Example 2: USD/JPY Bearish Trade (SHORT)

15-Minute Setup:
- Strong downtrend established (lower highs and lower lows)
- Order block identified in distribution zone

1-Minute Entry Sequence:
- Price enters 15-min OB zone
- Strong uptrend visible on 1-minute (correction within downtrend)
- Big red candle forms Change of Character (closes below recent higher low)
- New 1-minute order block generated from CHOCH movement

RSI Confirmation:
- Points A and B: price makes HIGHER HIGHS
- Points A and B: RSI makes LOWER HIGHS
- Bearish divergence confirmed

Execution:
- Entry: few pips below 1-min OB
- Stop loss: few pips above OB extreme (approximately 7 pips with spread)
- Reward: 45+ pips to next major structure
- Risk:Reward ratio: better than 6:1

Trade Outcome:
- First order filled (CHOCH entry)
- Second order: stop loss hit (part of normal scalping)
- Third order: NEW BOS generates new OB = order placed and ACTIVATED with profit
- Fourth order: NEW BOS generates new OB = order placed and ACTIVATED with profit
- Multiple winners offset stopped-out trade
- Net result: PROFITABLE trading session

Critical Lesson:
Never close trades before reaching targets. Patience allows institutional flow completion. Larger wins outweigh smaller losses through proper risk management.

ICT Mapping:
- Multiple OBs = institutional layering
- Each BOS = new institutional entry level
- Divergence at each level = momentum confirmation
- Stop hits = institutional cleanup/traps

15:31 - 15:59 | Closing Emphasis

Position Sizing Rule:
- CHOCH entry = full position size (standard risk)
- Subsequent entries = HALF position size
- Max 3 open positions per pair (mandatory)
- Maintains risk discipline as cascade continues

Critical Rules:
- Never close profitable trades before reaching targets
- Institutional flow needs time to complete
- Patience and discipline = larger profit capture
- Position sizing protects against over-exposure

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- 1-minute scalping combines order blocks, BOS, CHOCH, and RSI divergence for institutional-aligned entries with strict risk management.

- Order blocks are institutional liquidity zones formed by large money entering market; identified as last bearish candle before bullish move or vice versa.

- Break of Structure (BOS) signals trend continuation; Change of Character (CHOCH) signals reversal; CHOCH requires close beyond level (stricter).

- RSI divergence indicates momentum shift: bullish divergence (price lower lows, RSI higher lows) = long signal; bearish divergence (price higher highs, RSI lower highs) = short signal.

- Strategy Step 1: Analyze 15-minute timeframe; identify trend direction; mark institutional order blocks; wait for price to reach 15-min OB zone.

- Strategy Step 2: Switch to 1-minute; wait for Change of Character within 15-min OB; identify new 1-minute order blocks generated from CHOCH movement.

- Strategy Step 3: Add RSI to 1-minute chart; confirm with divergence signal aligned with entry direction (bullish for longs, bearish for shorts).

- Strategy Step 4: Enter few pips above/below 1-min OB; protect with stop loss at OB extreme; close 50% at 1:2 ratio; trail remainder to next structure.

- Multiple entry strategy: new Break of Structure creates new order block; place subsequent entry with HALF position size; maintain max 3 open positions per pair.

- Position sizing discipline: CHOCH entry = full size; subsequent entries = half-size; third entry = half-of-half; critical for risk management across cascade.

- Trading sessions include winners and losers; net profitability comes from larger wins outweighing smaller losses through disciplined risk management and position sizing.

- Never close profitable trades before reaching targets; institutional flow needs time to complete; patience and discipline maximize profit capture from institutional movement.


================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: Set 15-minute chart and identify current trend (uptrend or downtrend).
STEP 2: Mark swing highs (resistance) and swing lows (support) on 15-minute.
STEP 3: Locate most recent institutional order block.
STEP 4: Draw horizontal zone marking 15-minute order block.
STEP 5: Monitor price approaching 15-minute OB zone.
STEP 6: Switch to 1-minute timeframe when price enters/approaches 15-min OB.
STEP 7: Identify 1-minute trend direction and swing highs/lows for CHOCH reference.
STEP 8: Watch for Change of Character formation (break AND close beyond level).
STEP 9: Once CHOCH confirmed, identify new 1-minute order block generated by CHOCH.
STEP 10: Add RSI indicator to 1-minute chart.
STEP 11: Look for RSI divergence pattern (price one direction, RSI opposite).
STEP 12: Identify divergence type (bullish or bearish).
STEP 13: Confirm divergence aligns with intended trade direction.
STEP 14: Place entry order few pips ABOVE 1-min OB (long) or BELOW (short).
STEP 15: Set SL few pips beyond OB extreme (5-7 pips typical).
STEP 16: Calculate TP1 at 1:2 reward:risk; close 50% here.
STEP 17: Set TP2 at next 15-minute structure or trailing stop.
STEP 18: Monitor for additional BOS and new OB formations.
STEP 19: Place subsequent orders at HALF position size (max 3 total).
STEP 20: Never close trades before reaching targets; let institutional flow complete.

================================================================================
TRADING CHECKLISTS
================================================================================

A. 15-MINUTE MACRO ANALYSIS

- [ ] Timeframe set to 15-minute chart
- [ ] Current trend identified (uptrend or downtrend)
- [ ] Swing highs marked as resistance levels
- [ ] Swing lows marked as support levels
- [ ] Most recent institutional order block located
- [ ] Order block zone drawn (accumulation/distribution area)
- [ ] Price action approaching 15-min OB monitored
- [ ] No high-impact news events during setup
- [ ] Market liquidity adequate for scalping
- [ ] Confirmation: ready to switch to 1-minute chart

B. 1-MINUTE MICRO SETUP

- [ ] Timeframe switched to 1-minute chart
- [ ] Current 1-minute trend identified
- [ ] Swing highs/lows marked for CHOCH reference
- [ ] Price positioned within/approaching 15-min OB zone
- [ ] Monitoring for Change of Character formation
- [ ] CHOCH verified: break AND close beyond level
- [ ] 1-minute order block drawn from CHOCH movement
- [ ] RSI indicator added to 1-minute chart
- [ ] RSI divergence identified (bullish or bearish)
- [ ] Divergence confirmation: RSI crossing 30 (bullish) or 70 (bearish)
- [ ] All three confirmations aligned: 15-min OB + 1-min CHOCH + RSI divergence

C. ENTRY EXECUTION

- [ ] Entry direction confirmed (long/short)
- [ ] Entry order placed few pips above (long) or below (short) 1-min OB
- [ ] Stop loss calculated: few pips beyond OB extreme
- [ ] Stop loss order placed at calculated level
- [ ] Risk amount verified: acceptable percent of account
- [ ] Take profit 1 calculated: entry plus (2 x risk)
- [ ] TP1 order placed to close 50% position
- [ ] Take profit 2 planned: next structure or trailing stop
- [ ] TP2 order placed
- [ ] All orders active and correct

D. MULTIPLE ENTRY MANAGEMENT

- [ ] First position filled from CHOCH entry
- [ ] Monitoring for additional Break of Structure
- [ ] New order block identified from subsequent BOS
- [ ] Second entry placed: HALF position size
- [ ] Second order SL/TP configured with half-risk
- [ ] Monitoring for third BOS plus OB
- [ ] Third entry placed: HALF of half (if applicable)
- [ ] Max 3 open positions rule maintained
- [ ] No additional entries beyond 3-position limit
- [ ] Position sizing discipline enforced


Episode 10: 3 Best Smart Money Trading Strategy (Advanced)



00:00 - 00:59 | Introduction & Course Overview

Advanced course on smart money concepts - a trading system that follows institutional forces with market-pushing ability. Course covers demand/supply, market structure, and liquidity from smart money perspective. Also covers complete trading plan with three best smart money trading strategies known as sniper entries.

ICT Mapping:
- Smart money system = institutional methodology
- Sniper entries = precision institutional entry confirmation
- Demand/supply = institutional order clustering zones

00:59 - 07:02 | Smart Money Concepts Foundation

Core concept: smart money trading system with institutional power. Six key topics explained:

1. Supply and Demand: Zones where price rapidly pushes creating inefficiency, BOS, or CHOCH. Three factors for identification: inefficiency creation, structure break/character change, liquidity creation.

2. Inefficiency: Price gaps between candles; price tends to return to fill gaps later.

3. Break of Structure & Change of Character: BOS = trend continuation (same direction); CHOCH = trend reversal (opposite direction signaling possible reversal).

4. Liquidity: Institutional need for counterparty positions. Exist where support/resistance traders place stop losses. Zones marked by equal highs/lows.

5. Order Blocks: Optimized supply/demand zones (last recent candle creating inefficiency). Three rules: has inefficiency, leads to BOS/CHOCH, unmitigated (not yet tested).

6. Market Structure Control: Identify which side controls - supply or demand. Higher timeframe context determines bias. Trading with controlling side reduces risk.

ICT Mapping:
- Supply/demand zones = institutional liquidity clustering
- Inefficiency = institutional order imbalance
- Order blocks = unmitigated institutional entry zones
- Market control = institutional dominance assessment
- Liquidity zones = institutional stop-loss concentration

07:02 - 14:21 | Trading Plan & Entry Strategies

Trading Plan Framework:
Step 1: Analyze market structure in higher timeframes to find market direction, control, and optimal supply/demand zones/order blocks.
Step 2: Observe lower timeframes to execute trades based on three entry patterns.

Recommendation: Trade only ONE pair, ONE session. London and New York sessions best. Backtest thoroughly for chosen session.

Three Entry Patterns:

1. Supply and Demand Flip:
- Price creates new high, tests last demand zone, pushes away but fails
- Creates higher high but breaks demand zone impulsively (inefficiency)
- Supply zone remains
- Entry: When price retests supply level
- Order: Spread size below order block; SL couple pips above; target next demand in higher timeframe
- Most effective: Aggressive push from demand/supply + rapid inefficiency

2. Change of Character Pattern:
- Forms after mitigating higher timeframe supply/demand
- Trade only if higher timeframe direction aligned
- After mitigation: short-term trend changes character (inefficiency)
- Creates perfect supply/demand zone
- Entry: When price returns to this level
- Order: Spread size above/below 15-minute order block; SL at swing; target higher timeframe structure
- Most effective: Breaking through 2+ supply/demand zones after higher timeframe mitigation with large candles

3. Continuation Pattern:
- Trade only in clear trending market
- Entry: When valid order block forms (all rules met)
- Requires both higher and lower timeframe direction aligned
- Key: Patience and risk management (many entries, manage risk carefully)
- Pattern creates: wins, losses, wins - requires discipline

ICT Mapping:
- Trading plan = multi-timeframe institutional confirmation
- Supply/demand flip = institutional momentum loss + reversal
- CHOCH pattern = institutional direction shift
- Continuation = institutional trend alignment
- Sniper entries = confluence-based precision execution

14:21 - 16:38 | Multi-Timeframe Analysis Example & Closing

Live Trading Example (4-hour to 15-minute breakdown):
1. 4-hour: Price broke demand zone downside with inefficiency = order block formed = bearish bias
2. 1-hour: In uptrend; equal highs (liquidity zone for sellers); need reversal signals
3. 15-minute: Supply/demand flip pattern observed:
   - Market broke structure (inefficiency, extreme demand left)
   - Testing demand zone: failed new higher high (momentum loss)
   - Market breaks demand downside with momentum (trend change signal)
   - Created order block supply zone = sell opportunity
4. Entry: Sell order spread size below order block; SL above swing high; target next structure
5. Management: Track profit by adjusting SL and securing profits with new order blocks

Closing: Video teaches advanced trading concepts using multi-timeframe analysis with supply/demand flips, change of character, and continuation patterns.

ICT Mapping:
- 4-hour analysis = macro institutional direction
- 1-hour analysis = intermediate institutional control
- 15-minute analysis = micro institutional entry execution
- Multi-timeframe confluence = maximum institutional alignment
- Profit tracking = institutional order flow following

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- Advanced smart money trading system aligns with institutional forces; course covers demand/supply, market structure, liquidity, and three sniper entry strategies.

- Supply and demand zones form through inefficiency (price gaps) and institutional need for counterparty positions; identified by inefficiency, BOS/CHOCH, and liquidity creation.

- Inefficiency = price gaps between candles indicating imbalance; price tends to return filling gaps later (institutional target area).

- Break of Structure (BOS) signals trend continuation in same direction; Change of Character (CHOCH) signals potential trend reversal in opposite direction.

- Order blocks are optimized supply/demand zones (last candle creating inefficiency) with three requirements: inefficiency, BOS/CHOCH formation, unmitigated (untested).

- Market control determines trading direction: higher timeframe analysis reveals which side (supply/demand) has control; trade with controlling side.

- Trading plan: Step 1 = analyze higher timeframe market structure/control/zones; Step 2 = execute lower timeframe trades based on three patterns.

- Recommendation: Trade one pair in one session (London/New York best); backtest thoroughly for chosen session.

- Supply/demand flip: price fails to make new highs, breaks demand zone with momentum, creates supply zone for entry.

- Change of character pattern: forms after higher timeframe mitigation; entry when price retests zone; most effective with 2+ zone breaks and large candles.

- Continuation pattern: trade clear trending market with valid order blocks; requires both timeframe direction alignment; needs patience and strict risk management.

- Multi-timeframe analysis: 4-hour (macro), 1-hour (intermediate), 15-minute (micro); confluence of all three creates optimal entry opportunities.


================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: Identify supply/demand zones using three factors: inefficiency creation, BOS/CHOCH formation, liquidity existence.

STEP 2: Understand inefficiency = price gaps between candles indicating institutional imbalance; price returns to fill gaps.

STEP 3: Recognize BOS (trend continuation) vs CHOCH (trend reversal) patterns in price structure.

STEP 4: Validate order blocks: has inefficiency, leads to BOS/CHOCH, and is unmitigated (untested).

STEP 5: Determine market control by checking higher timeframe: identify supply or demand zone that price came from.

STEP 6: Select one trading pair and one session (London or New York recommended).

STEP 7: Backtest thoroughly for chosen pair/session combination over several months.

STEP 8: Analyze 4-hour timeframe for macro direction and institutional control (bearish or bullish bias).

STEP 9: Identify 4-hour order blocks and supply/demand zones (areas of interest).

STEP 10: Switch to 1-hour timeframe; identify intermediate trend and liquidity zones (equal highs/lows).

STEP 11: Confirm 1-hour direction aligns with 4-hour macro bias for entry.

STEP 12: Switch to 15-minute timeframe for entry execution.

STEP 13: Look for supply/demand flip: price fails new highs, breaks demand with momentum, creates supply zone.

STEP 14: Look for change of character: after mitigation, trend reverses with inefficiency, creates entry zone.

STEP 15: Look for continuation: valid order block forms in trending market with 4-hour and 15-minute alignment.

STEP 16: Place entry order: spread size below (shorts) or above (longs) order block zone.

STEP 17: Set stop loss: couple pips above (shorts) or below (longs) at swing extreme.

STEP 18: Set take profit: target next supply/demand zone in 4-hour timeframe.

STEP 19: Track profit continuously by adjusting stop loss following new order blocks.

STEP 20: Manage risk carefully; expect wins and losses; key to success = patience and discipline.

TRADING CHECKLISTS
================================================================================

A. 4-HOUR MACRO ANALYSIS

- [ ] Timeframe set to 4-hour chart
- [ ] Market direction identified (bullish or bearish trend)
- [ ] Current control determined (supply or demand side)
- [ ] Recent order blocks identified with inefficiency
- [ ] Supply and demand zones marked clearly
- [ ] Unmitigated zones identified (potential trading areas)
- [ ] Price trajectory analyzed (where it came from)
- [ ] Higher timeframe bias established (bearish or bullish)
- [ ] Area of interest pinpointed for lower timeframe entry
- [ ] 4-hour setup confirmed before zooming lower

B. 1-HOUR INTERMEDIATE ANALYSIS

- [ ] Timeframe switched to 1-hour chart
- [ ] Current 1-hour trend identified
- [ ] 1-hour direction compared to 4-hour bias
- [ ] Direction alignment confirmed (matching or conflicting)
- [ ] Liquidity zones identified (equal highs/lows)
- [ ] Institutional stop-loss concentration areas noted
- [ ] Reversal signals assessed before entering
- [ ] Support and resistance levels marked
- [ ] 1-hour confluence with 4-hour confirmed
- [ ] Ready to zoom into 15-minute for entry

C. 15-MINUTE ENTRY EXECUTION

- [ ] Timeframe switched to 15-minute chart
- [ ] Entry pattern identified (flip, CHOCH, or continuation)
- [ ] Supply/demand flip: price failed new highs? YES/NO
- [ ] Supply/demand flip: impulsive break through demand? YES/NO
- [ ] CHOCH: mitigation of higher timeframe zone complete? YES/NO
- [ ] CHOCH: inefficiency and trend reversal formed? YES/NO
- [ ] Continuation: valid order block with all rules met? YES/NO
- [ ] Entry order placed at correct zone (spread size from OB)
- [ ] Stop loss set at swing extreme (couple pips protection)
- [ ] Take profit targeted at next 4-hour structure level

D. RISK MANAGEMENT & PROFIT TRACKING

- [ ] Initial position size calculated based on account
- [ ] Risk amount acceptable per trade verified
- [ ] Stop loss distance measured and documented
- [ ] Take profit distance calculated (1:2+ ratio target)
- [ ] Entry price confirmed at order placement
- [ ] Stop loss order active and correct
- [ ] TP order active and correct
- [ ] Profit tracking initiated (new OB monitoring)
- [ ] Stop loss adjusted following new order blocks
- [ ] Partial profits secured on new OB formations


Episode 11: Smart Money Concept Trading Strategy Backtest



00:00 - 00:50 | Introduction & Backtest Overview

Video purpose: Show backtest results of smart money trading strategy created based on smart money concepts. After hours of backtesting, presenter discovered pros, cons, and exciting win rate results. Strategy tested using Soft4FX on MetaTrader4 (Forex simulator with real data). Test conditions: $10,000 initial account, 2% risk per trade, 3-month backtest period, London open through New York close only.

ICT Mapping:
- Backtest = systematic institutional strategy validation
- Win rate = institutional edge measurement
- Time-frame selection = institutional session alignment
- Risk management = institutional position sizing discipline

00:50 - 01:57 | Trading Strategy Rules & Logic - Part 1

Step 1: Analyze market direction and mark high potential order blocks on 1-hour timeframe.

Example: Demand in control, market broke structure upside with inefficiency, perfect order block demand zone formed, room for price to rise before higher timeframe supply zone.

Step 2: Wait for price to reach order block, then zoom into 5-minute timeframe for entry execution.

Entry requirement: Change of Character formation signals short-term downtrend is over; market can move upside.

No CHOCH = no trade (critical filter).

ICT Mapping:
- 1-hour analysis = macro institutional control assessment
- Order blocks = unmitigated institutional liquidity zones
- CHOCH filter = institutional momentum confirmation

01:57 - 02:50 | Trading Strategy Rules & Logic - Part 2

Entry Scenarios:

Scenario 1 (with Order Block):
- If CHOCH creates efficiency/order block
- Entry: spread size above order block
- Stop loss: couple pips below swing low

Scenario 2 (without Order Block):
- If CHOCH doesn't create order block
- Entry: middle of 61.8% and 78.6% Fibonacci retracement
- Stop loss: couple pips below swing low

Take Profit Management:
- Track profit by repositioning stop below each new order block
- Continue until reaching higher timeframe supply zone
- Achieves significant profit without pressure

Bearish Scenario:
- All logic applies inverted (shorting instead of longing)

ICT Mapping:
- Scenario 1 = institutional order block confirmation
- Scenario 2 = institutional Fibonacci absorption zones
- Profit tracking = institutional order flow following
- Multi-scenario = institutional flexibility

02:50 - 05:03 | Backtest Results & Analysis

Testing Period: 3 months on EUR/USD, London to New York sessions

Results Summary:
- Win rate: not high but profitable
- Net profit: 68% gain
- Important caveat: live trading will likely show lower returns (emotions factor)

Advantages of Strategy:

1. Simplicity & Rule-Based
- Not multiple indicators/lines
- Clear rules, easy implementation
- Know exactly what to look for

2. CHOCH Entry Filter
- Saves from many losses
- Prevents trades when other side highly in control
- Ignores false order blocks

3. Profit Tracking System
- 1 in 10 trades can produce large moves
- Tracking profits captures significant reward
- Better than fixed 1:2 targets
- Requires patience and time discipline

Considerations:
- Backtest results may not reflect live performance
- Emotions impact real trading
- Discipline required for profit tracking method

ICT Mapping:
- Strategy advantage = institutional simplicity
- CHOCH advantage = institutional momentum confirmation precision
- Profit tracking = institutional flow maximization
- Live vs backtest = institutional psychological variables

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- Backtest of smart money trading strategy on EUR/USD over 3 months shows 68% profit gain using London-to-New York session focus.

- Strategy uses 2% risk per trade on $10,000 account, creating disciplined position sizing aligned with institutional risk management.

- Step 1: Analyze 1-hour timeframe for market direction and institutional control (demand or supply); mark high-potential order blocks.

- Step 2: Wait for price reaching order block, then zoom 5-minute timeframe; require Change of Character formation as critical entry filter.

- Entry Scenario 1: CHOCH creates order block; entry spread size above block; SL couple pips below swing low.

- Entry Scenario 2: CHOCH without order block; entry at 61.8%-78.6% Fibonacci retracement middle; SL couple pips below swing.

- Take profit method: Track profit by repositioning stop loss below new order blocks until reaching higher timeframe supply zone; captures large moves.

- Strategy advantages: Simple and rule-based (no multiple indicators); CHOCH filter prevents many losses; profit tracking captures oversized institutional moves.

- Backtest results show non-high win rate but 68% profit gain; live performance expected lower due to emotional factors.

- CHOCH entry filter helps avoid trades when opposite side highly in control; prevents entries into false order blocks.

- Profit tracking system potentially more rewarding than fixed targets; requires more patience but captures institutional flow extensions.

- Three-month test period, London-New York session only; strategy scalable to other pairs and timeframes with same logic.

================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: Set timeframe to 1-hour chart for market analysis.

STEP 2: Identify current market direction (uptrend or downtrend).

STEP 3: Determine which side controls market (demand or supply dominance).

STEP 4: Locate recent institutional order blocks on 1-hour chart.

STEP 5: Verify order blocks have inefficiency and led to BOS/CHOCH.

STEP 6: Verify order blocks are unmitigated (untested by price).

STEP 7: Mark high-potential order blocks for trading entries.

STEP 8: Monitor price approaching marked 1-hour order blocks.

STEP 9: When price reaches order block area, switch to 5-minute timeframe.

STEP 10: Analyze 5-minute trend direction when price in order block zone.

STEP 11: Wait for Change of Character formation on 5-minute timeframe.

STEP 12: Confirm CHOCH: short-term downtrend breaks upside with inefficiency.

STEP 13: If CHOCH creates order block: entry spread size above the block.

STEP 14: If CHOCH doesn't create order block: entry at Fibonacci 61.8%-78.6% middle.

STEP 15: Place stop loss: couple pips below swing low point.

STEP 16: Calculate initial risk from entry to stop loss.

STEP 17: Monitor price movement after entry execution.

STEP 18: When price creates new order block, reposition stop loss below it.

STEP 19: Continue profit tracking, repositioning SL with each new OB formed.

STEP 20: Close position when price reaches higher timeframe supply/demand zone or market reverses.

================================================================================

- [ ] Order blocks verified for BOS/CHOCH formation
- [ ] Order blocks verified as unmitigated (untested)
- [ ] High-potential OBs selected for trading focus
- [ ] Higher timeframe supply zone identified (target reference)
- [ ] Sufficient room for price movement analyzed

B. 5-MINUTE ENTRY CONFIRMATION

- [ ] Timeframe switched to 5-minute chart
- [ ] Price position in 1-hour order block zone confirmed
- [ ] Current 5-minute trend identified
- [ ] Monitoring for Change of Character formation
- [ ] CHOCH break and close past level confirmed
- [ ] CHOCH creates inefficiency verified
- [ ] Inefficiency/order block formation identified
- [ ] Entry type determined (with OB or without OB)
- [ ] Fibonacci retracement levels calculated (61.8% and 78.6%)
- [ ] Entry price level determined

C. ENTRY EXECUTION & RISK SETUP

- [ ] Entry scenario confirmed (OB present or Fibonacci entry)
- [ ] Entry order placed at correct level (spread size from OB or Fibonacci middle)
- [ ] Stop loss calculated: couple pips below swing low
- [ ] Stop loss order placed at exact level
- [ ] Risk amount calculated from entry to SL
- [ ] Risk acceptable per trading plan verified
- [ ] Position size calculated for 2% account risk

- [ ] Profit tracking method understood (SL repositioning)
- [ ] Chart labeled and orders confirmed active

D. PROFIT TRACKING & MANAGEMENT

- [ ] Entry filled, initial SL in place
- [ ] Monitoring price movement from entry
- [ ] Watching for new order block formations
- [ ] When new OB forms: SL repositioned below it
- [ ] Profit tracking documented with each repositioning
- [ ] New OBs continuously identified as price moves
- [ ] SL adjusted with each new OB formation
- [ ] Emotional discipline maintained (no early closes)
- [ ] Exit near higher timeframe supply/demand zone
- [ ] Trade closed at predetermined exit level or reversal

Episode 12: Best 1 Minute Order Block Trading Strategy to Grow Small Account


00:00 - 01:02 | Introduction & Strategy Overview

Advanced gold scalping strategy on XAUUSD (gold/US dollar) pair combining smart money concepts with RSI divergence. Strategy is extremely accurate and trustworthy. Uses indicators as confirmation only, not entry reason. Shows multiple live trading examples on gold pair. Goal: Teach advanced scalping methodology for small account growth.

ICT Mapping:
- Gold scalping = micro institutional movement capture
- Smart money + RSI = dual institutional confirmation
- 1-minute scalping = institutional order fill timing

01:02 - 02:16 | Strategy Prerequisites & Four-Step Framework

Prerequisites (explained in detail in previous episodes):
- Order blocks (unmitigated institutional liquidity zones)
- Break of Structure (BOS) and Change of Character (CHOCH)
- RSI divergence (momentum confirmation)
- Price structure and liquidity

Four-Step Strategy Framework:

Step 1: Analyze 15-minute timeframe; draw order blocks; wait for price to reach
Step 2: Zoom 1-minute timeframe; wait for Change of Character; identify new 1-min OBs
Step 3: Add RSI to 1-minute; look for divergence signals as entry confirmation
Step 4: Place trade in 1-minute order block with defined risk management

ICT Mapping:
- Step 1 = macro institutional structure (15-min)
- Step 2 = micro institutional momentum (1-min)
- Step 3 = institutional momentum confirmation (RSI)
- Step 4 = precision institutional entry execution

02:16 - 08:07 | Live Example 1: Bullish Trade (Gold XAUUSD)

Setup Identification:
- 15-minute: Big green momentum candle sweeps liquidity (equal highs), creates imbalance and BOS
- Order block demand zone formed with room to rise before hitting 15-min supply zone
- Price enters 15-min OB zone (CHOCH opportunity point)

1-Minute Entry Execution:
- Price in strong downtrend on 1-minute when entering 15-min OB
- Change of Character: Price breaks and closes ABOVE recent lower high = trend reversal signal
- New 1-minute order block created from CHOCH movement

RSI Confirmation:
- Points A and B: Price makes LOWER LOWS
- Points A and B: RSI makes HIGHER LOWS = Bullish divergence âœ“
- Entry confirmation complete

Trade Execution:
- Entry: Middle of 1-minute order block (optimized entry = 50% lower SL)
- Stop loss: Couple pips below swing low (~6-7 pips)
- TP1: Close 50% at 1:2 ratio (breakeven protection)
- TP2: Track profits with SL repositioning at each new OB formed

Multiple Entry Cascade:
- First CHOCH entry creates OB1 (full position size)
- BOS creates OB2 (half position size entry)
- Alpha order block: When liquidity zones form before OB, order block gains importance
- Subsequent entries use reduced position sizing

Result: Second order stopped out; third and fourth orders activated; position moved upward with momentum candles; reached 15-minute major structure for profit

ICT Mapping:
- 15-min BOS = institutional momentum initiation
- 1-min CHOCH = micro institutional momentum confirmation
- Bullish divergence = institutional buying detection
- Optimized entry (middle) = institutional precision
- Multiple OBs = cascading institutional orders

08:07 - 12:39 | Live Example 2: Bearish Trade (Gold XAUUSD)

Setup Identification:
- 15-minute: Big red momentum candle sweeps liquidity (equal lows), creates imbalance and BOS downside
- Order block supply zone formed = potential selling opportunity
- Price enters 15-min OB zone (CHOCH opportunity point)

1-Minute Entry Execution:
- Price in strong uptrend on 1-minute when entering 15-min OB
- Change of Character: Price breaks and closes BELOW recent higher high = trend reversal signal
- New 1-minute order block created from CHOCH movement (bearish setup)

RSI Confirmation:
- Points A and B: Price makes HIGHER HIGHS
- Points A and B: RSI makes LOWER HIGHS = Bearish divergence âœ“
- Entry confirmation complete

Trade Execution:
- Entry: Middle of 1-minute order block
- Stop loss: Couple pips ABOVE swing high (~6 pips on gold)
- Reward: 45+ pips to 15-minute structure
- Risk:Reward ratio: More than 7:1

Multiple Entry Cascade:
- First CHOCH entry creates OB1 (full size)
- Second order: Stop loss hit (normal in scalping)
- Third order: New BOS creates new OB, entry placed, activated with profit
- Fourth order: New BOS creates new OB, entry placed, activated with profit

Result: First order moved to profit despite later SL hit; subsequent orders captured profit; total session = modest loss offset by larger wins = profitable

ICT Mapping:
- 15-min BOS downside = institutional selling initiation
- 1-min CHOCH = micro institutional selling momentum
- Bearish divergence = institutional selling detection
- 7:1 risk:reward = institutional edge captured

12:39 - 15:00 | Live Example 3, Risk Management Rules & Closing

Live Example 3 (Bullish):
- 15-minute: Green candle with big momentum sweeps liquidity, creates OB demand zone
- Price reaches 15-min OB, 1-min CHOCH forms with bullish divergence
- Three successful long entries cascade from this setup
- All orders activated, TP reached at 15-minute structure

Risk Management Rules:

Position Sizing:
- CHOCH entry (OB1) = full position size
- Subsequent entries (OB2, OB3, etc.) = half position size each
- Maximum: 5 open positions per pair (prevents over-exposure)

Profit Management:
- Close 50% position at 1:2 ratio (locks breakeven)
- Reposition SL below each new OB as price moves
- Continue tracking until reaching higher timeframe structure
- Never close trades before targets (allows institutional flow completion)

Key Lesson:
Modest losses acceptable; wins outweigh losses through larger profit capture and position sizing discipline

Closing Remarks:
Lost modest capital during trading session; winnings much outweighed losses. Key message: never terminate trades before price reaches targets. Encouraging viewer engagement: subscribe for weekly videos; share opinions and suggest topics in comments.

ICT Mapping:
- Position sizing = institutional capital preservation
- Profit tracking = institutional flow maximization
- Multiple small positions = institutional layering
- SL repositioning = institutional trend following
- Psychological discipline = institutional execution mastery

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- Advanced gold scalping strategy combines smart money order blocks with RSI divergence on 1-minute timeframe using 15-minute macro structure.

- Strategy uses 4 steps: 1) Analyze 15-min OBs; 2) Wait 1-min CHOCH and identify OBs; 3) Confirm RSI divergence; 4) Execute 1-min OB entry.

- Entry requirement: Change of Character on 1-minute shows institutional momentum reversal; no CHOCH = no trade (critical filter).

- RSI divergence confirms institutional momentum: bullish divergence (price lower lows, RSI higher lows) signals long; bearish (price higher highs, RSI lower highs) signals short.

- Entry optimization: Place entry at MIDDLE of 1-minute order block; reduces stop loss by ~50% compared to standard entry; improves risk:reward ratio.

- Position sizing rule: CHOCH entry = full size; OB2 entry = half-size; OB3 = quarter-size; maximum 5 open positions per pair prevents over-exposure.

- Profit management: Close 50% position at 1:2 ratio (locks breakeven); reposition SL below each new OB as price moves; continue until reaching 15-min structure.

- Multiple entry cascade: Each Break of Structure creates new institutional order block; subsequent entries with reduced size capture additional profits from institutional layering.

- Alpha order blocks: When liquidity zones form before order block, that OB gains increased importance; price has stronger tendency to respect; higher probability entry.

- Bullish trade example: 15-min BOS up + 1-min CHOCH + bullish divergence = long setup; multiple entries captured 3 winning positions reaching 15-min structure.

- Bearish trade example: 15-min BOS down + 1-min CHOCH + bearish divergence = short setup; 7:1 risk:reward ratio; first order profit offset losses on second order.

- Emotional discipline critical: Accept modest losses; patient position tracking captures larger wins; key to profitability with small account growth.

================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: Set 15-minute chart to gold US dollar pair (XAUUSD).

STEP 2: Identify current trend direction on 15-minute timeframe.

STEP 3: Watch for big momentum candles that break recent price structure.

STEP 4: Mark the liquidity zones (equal highs or equal lows) before BOS.

STEP 5: Identify order block zone created by institutional BOS with imbalance.

STEP 6: Monitor price approaching 15-minute order block zone.

STEP 7: Switch to 1-minute timeframe when price enters 15-min OB area.

STEP 8: Analyze 1-minute trend (uptrend or downtrend at OB entry point).

STEP 9: Wait for Change of Character formation on 1-minute timeframe.

STEP 10: Confirm CHOCH: price breaks AND closes beyond structural level with inefficiency.

STEP 11: Identify new 1-minute order block created from CHOCH movement.

STEP 12: Add RSI indicator to 1-minute chart for divergence confirmation.

STEP 13: Identify RSI divergence pattern (bullish or bearish).

STEP 14: Confirm divergence aligns with intended entry direction.

STEP 15: Place entry order at MIDDLE of 1-minute order block (not edge).

STEP 16: Set stop loss couple pips beyond order block extreme.

STEP 17: Calculate initial risk from entry to stop loss.

STEP 18: Close 50% position at 1:2 reward:risk ratio (breakeven protection).

STEP 19: Reposition stop loss below new order blocks as price moves.

STEP 20: Monitor for new Break of Structure creating additional OBs.
