Episode 13: Liquidity Trading Strategy - Smart Money Concepts

================================================================================
EXPLANATION: BREAKDOWN BY TIMESTAMPS
================================================================================

00:00 - 00:52 | Introduction & Video Overview

Welcome to advanced liquidity trading concepts tutorial. Understanding liquidity will instantly improve entries and exits, reduce losses, and help catch high risk:reward ratio trades. Video covers three main topics: powerful liquidity concept from smart money perspective, identification of liquidity grab moves on charts, and rule-based liquidity trading strategy with specific entry and exit points.

ICT Mapping:
- Liquidity = institutional money concentration zones
- Liquidity grab = institutional predatory movement to take retail stops
- Liquidity trading = exploiting retail stop clustering for institutional profit

00:52 - 02:36 | What Is Liquidity & Where It Exists

Liquidity Definition:
Liquidity basically means money. Every trade is transaction between buyers and sellers. More money in market makes it easier for big institutional players to execute large trades without moving price.

Real World Example:
Huge company needs to exchange hundreds of millions of dollars into euros. If done when liquidity is low, price skyrockets unfavorably. Solution: Need liquidity (sellers in market) to buy cheap before executing massive volume purchase. This is institutional thinking applied to forex.

Where Liquidity Zones Exist:
Liquidity is where retail traders congregate. When price reaches demand zones, retail traders place buy orders with sell stop losses below. This creates liquidity zones below demand areas. Same applies to support/resistance levels where traders cluster their orders with stops. Perfect setup occurs when liquidity zones align with order blocks, giving institutions perfect opportunity to grab liquidity and continue price move.

ICT Mapping:
- Retail demand zones = liquidity clustering points
- Stop loss levels = institutional hunting grounds
- Support/resistance = retail trader concentration
- Aligned OB + liquidity = institutional setup perfection

02:36 - 04:02 | Benefits Of Identifying Liquidity Zones

Benefit 1: Fuel For Institutional Moves
Existing liquidity zone before demand or supply area makes perfect trading opportunity because liquidity acts as fuel for price movements institutions want to execute. Without liquidity, institutions cannot move price efficiently.

Benefit 2: Distinguish High-Probability Entries
Identifying liquidity areas with less probability of working versus major demand and supply zones helps traders promote better entries and run into fewer losses. Not all liquidity is equal; some has higher probability than others.

Live Chart Example:
Price broke through structure level with inefficiency, leaving perfect order block. If price returns to fill gap, excellent opportunity to place buy orders in order block zone. After sharp move, trend exhausted and created multiple liquidity zones. Price broke support levels, took out early buyers (grabbed liquidity), continued moving upside. Key insight: Grabbing liquidity before reaching order block creates perfect opportunity, though not law because price can break OB and lead to major trend change. Always confirm reversal pattern on lower timeframes before placing trades.

ICT Mapping:
- Trend exhaustion = liquidity zone creation
- Pre-OB liquidity grab = institutional setup
- Lower timeframe confirmation = entry precision
- Multiple grabs = institutional layering

04:02 - 05:23 | Types Of Liquidity On Charts

Liquidity Types:
Trend lines, consolidation areas, major moving averages, and equal highs and lows all represent liquidity zones. Keep things simple and focus on equal highs and lows primarily.

Distinguishing Major Supply/Demand From Liquidity:
Starting from left: nice move upside with inefficiency creates opportunity to wait for price pullback and fill gap in order block zone. Opposite color candle creates inefficiency representing perfect demand level for trading. Major level of structure acts as both support and resistance multiple times, representing perfect buying opportunity. Classification method: distinguish major supply and demand from liquidity areas by combining inefficiency, structure breaks, and level importance.

ICT Mapping:
- Equal highs/lows = retail clustering points
- Inefficiency zones = institutional accumulation
- Major structure levels = repeated institutional interaction
- Color confluence = entry signal strength

05:23 - 08:50 | Liquidity Trading Strategy & Execution

Strategy Overview:
Not limited to timeframes, applicable to forex, crypto, stocks. Two major steps: identify trend, execute liquidity sweep.

Step 1 - Identify Trend Using EMA 50:
Apply EMA 50 to chart. Price must break EMA in one direction with one-two-three moves where third move breaks previous market structure level. This confirms trend bias.

Step 2 - Liquidity Sweep Pattern Entry:
Wait for price to make support level. Entry trigger: wick below support (grabbing liquidity) or close below and return above. Entry timing: right after wick or confirmation candle closing higher than previous. Stop loss: below long-wick candlestick. Take profit: next market structure level.

Risk Management:
Close 50% position at 1:2 target ratio (locks breakeven). Continue remaining position to next structure level.

Critical Step:
Always look at higher timeframe before entry. Verify price has room to reach next structure level. Example: 15-minute chart confirms structure break with plenty room to next level. Confirmation: price has space to move without hitting resistance.

Bearish Example (EUR/USD 15-minute):
Market broke EMA 50 downside with one-two-three moves establishing bearish bias. Market made resistance and broke above it (liquidity grab). Immediately returned to range (failed breakout signal). Execute short entry after liquidity grab and rejection.

Strategy Backtest:
Backtest on your own charts to find best pair/timeframe combinations. Same logic applies inverted to bearish scenarios. Strategy works all timeframes and markets.

ICT Mapping:
- EMA 50 break = institutional momentum initiation
- 1-2-3 structure break = institutional power confirmation
- Liquidity sweep = institutional stop-hunt execution
- Failed breakout = institutional rejection signal
- Higher timeframe room = institutional movement capacity

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- Liquidity equals money and traders in market; identifying liquidity zones improves entries, exits, and risk:reward ratios dramatically.

- Liquidity exists where retail traders congregate: demand zones with sell stops below, support/resistance levels with trader orders, equal highs and lows.

- Institutional operators grab liquidity by taking out retail stops BEFORE moving price in intended direction, creating sharp moves after liquidity capture.

- Liquidity zones identified by equal highs and lows, trend lines, consolidations, moving averages; keep focus simple using equal highs and lows primarily.

- Pre-order-block liquidity zones provide perfect institutional entries; liquidity grabs act as fuel for continuation moves in established trends.

- Trading setup: Apply EMA 50, identify trend with 1-2-3 moves breaking structure, wait for liquidity sweep at support/resistance.

- Liquidity sweep entry: Price wicks below support grabbing retail stops, or closes below and returns above; enter wick or confirmation candle.

- Stop loss placed below long-wick candlestick (typically 3-5 pips); take profit targets next major structure level in higher timeframe.

- Risk management: Close 50% at 1:2 ratio locking breakeven; continue remaining position tracking to next institutional structure.

- Higher timeframe confirmation critical: Ensure price has sufficient room to move to next structural level before entering; prevents entries near resistance.

- Failed breakout pattern: Price breaks support, grabs liquidity above, returns to range immediately equals bearish signal for lower timeframe shorts.

- Strategy works all timeframes and markets including forex, crypto, stocks; backtest thoroughly to find optimal pair/timeframe/session combinations.

================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: Select trading pair and set EMA 50 indicator on chart.

STEP 2: Identify current trend direction on chart (up or down).

STEP 3: Watch for price to break EMA 50 in one direction clearly.

STEP 4: Identify first move after EMA break (move 1 = new high/low).

STEP 5: Identify pullback or retracement movement (move 2).

STEP 6: Identify return move in break direction (move 3).

STEP 7: Confirm move 3 breaks previous market structure level.

STEP 8: Establish trend bias (bullish if breaks up, bearish if breaks down).

STEP 9: Locate support or resistance level aligned with established trend.

STEP 10: Monitor price approaching the support/resistance level.

STEP 11: Watch for wick below support level (liquidity grab signal).

STEP 12: Alternatively accept close below support followed by return above.

STEP 13: Identify entry point timing (wick formation or confirmation candle).

STEP 14: Switch to higher timeframe and verify room to next structure.

STEP 15: Confirm higher timeframe shows price has space to move.

STEP 16: Calculate stop loss distance below long-wick candlestick (3-5 pips).

STEP 17: Place stop loss order at calculated level.

STEP 18: Identify take profit target at next major structure level.

STEP 19: Place entry order at liquidity sweep point.

STEP 20: Monitor trade execution and exit per plan.

================================================================================
TRADING CHECKLISTS
================================================================================

A. TREND IDENTIFICATION WITH EMA 50

- [ ] EMA 50 added to chart
- [ ] Current price position vs EMA identified
- [ ] Price break direction confirmed (up or down)
- [ ] Move 1 identified after break
- [ ] Move 2 pullback completed
- [ ] Move 3 identified (return to break direction)
- [ ] Move 3 breaks previous market structure
- [ ] Trend bias established (bullish or bearish)
- [ ] Support/resistance level marked
- [ ] Ready for liquidity sweep monitoring

B. SUPPORT/RESISTANCE & LIQUIDITY ZONE ANALYSIS

- [ ] Support level identified for bullish trades
- [ ] Support has retail trader involvement confirmed
- [ ] Liquidity zone exists below support level
- [ ] Higher timeframe shows room to target
- [ ] Next major structural level identified above
- [ ] Price monitored approaching support level
- [ ] No conflicting resistance between entry and target
- [ ] Liquidity zone verified as major institutional level
- [ ] Ready for liquidity sweep pattern
- [ ] Setup complete for entry execution

C. LIQUIDITY SWEEP ENTRY EXECUTION

- [ ] Monitoring price approaching support level
- [ ] Wick below support formed (liquidity grab candle)
- [ ] Long wick extends below support 3-5 pips
- [ ] Entry trigger confirmed (wick or close-return)
- [ ] Confirmation candle identified (if using confirmation)
- [ ] Higher timeframe reconfirmed for room to target
- [ ] Stop loss calculated below long wick
- [ ] Stop loss order placed at exact level
- [ ] Entry order placed at wick level or after confirmation
- [ ] Risk amount calculated and verified acceptable

D. TRADE MANAGEMENT & PROFIT TRACKING

- [ ] Entry filled at liquidity sweep point
- [ ] Stop loss active and monitored
- [ ] TP1 calculated at 1:2 reward:risk ratio
- [ ] Higher timeframe target confirmed
- [ ] 50% position close preparation ready
- [ ] Remaining 50% position monitored continuously
- [ ] Higher timeframe structure checked regularly
- [ ] Trade tracking ongoing (stop not adjusted until confirmation)
- [ ] 50% position closed at TP1 (breakeven protection)
- [ ] Remaining position tracked to main target or closed


Episode 14: 3 Best Order Block Indicators on TradingView

================================================================================
EXPLANATION: BREAKDOWN BY TIMESTAMPS
================================================================================

00:00 - 00:57 | Introduction & Episode Overview

Welcome to episode on top three order block indicators for TradingView. Spotting and having valid order blocks on charts improves trading success. Video covers: top three order block indicators, how to add and set up indicators on trading charts, and backtesting results from last 6 months on EUR/USD pair. Backtesting uses SOFT 4 FX software on MetaTrader 4 platform, a real database Forex simulator. Episode shows win rates and results from actual trades based on these indicators. Channel focuses on advanced trading concepts, strategies, entry reasons, and trading discipline.

ICT Mapping:
- Order blocks = institutional accumulation/distribution zones
- Market structure break = institutional momentum confirmation
- Supply/demand zones = order block functionality
- Backtesting = institutional strategy validation

00:57 - 03:27 | Indicator 1: Market Structure Break and Order Block

First Indicator Setup:
Access TradingView indicator tab, search "Market Structure Break and Order Block", add to chart. Display shows EUR/USD daily timeframe. Settings accessible by double-clicking indicator bar.

Settings Overview:
Zigzag length adjustable, can hide zigzag pattern by unchecking box, Fibonacci Factor value changes breakout confirmation. Recommendation: Do not change default values - indicator performs optimally at defaults.

How Indicator Works:
Shows market structure break (MSB) and order blocks. Bullish breakout occurs when price breaks most recent higher high (green MSB). Bearish breakout when price breaks most recent low (red MSB). Includes zigzag patterns for easy high/low spotting. Order blocks function as supply and demand zones.

Live Examples:
EUR/USD daily: Price reached bullish order block, reversed, continued upside with momentum candles. Possible long entry at red candle closure. 1-hour frame: Bullish MSB with bullish order block. Price respected demand zone multiple times. Long entry at red hammer candle closure. 15-minute frame: Bearish order block created by MSB. Price rejected multiple times from zone. Short entry after rejection.

ICT Mapping:
- Zigzag = institutional pivot identification
- MSB = institutional direction confirmation
- Order blocks = institutional entry zones
- Price rejection = institutional stop hunting

03:27 - 08:25 | Indicator 2: Order Block Finder Experimental

Indicator Setup:
Search "Order Block Finder Experimental" in TradingView, add to chart. Access settings by double-clicking indicator bar.

Settings Configuration:
Color scheme options: dark or bright (dark theme preferred). Relevant periods tab: choose how many order blocks displayed on chart (recommend 3). Style menu: customize text/line colors (optional). No changes needed - defaults work well.

Functionality:
Displays bearish and bullish order block zones as supply and demand zones. Price expected to change direction at these zones. Bullish order block zones for long positions. Bearish order block zones for short positions.

Daily Timeframe Analysis:
Price respected bearish order block zones repeatedly with downward rejection each time. Uptrend created bullish order block. Price reached bullish block, reversed upward. However, price did not respect two bearish blocks because uptrend has minor tendency to respect bearish blocks.

Multi-Timeframe Usage:
Indicator works across all timeframes: 1 hour, 30 minutes, 15 minutes, 1 minute. 4-hour timeframe shows price respecting bullish order block, reversing upward after touching zone.

ICT Mapping:
- Trend bias + order blocks = confluence
- Multi-timeframe blocks = institutional alignment
- Block rejection = momentum confirmation
- Supply/demand zones = execution points

08:25 - 09:09 | Indicator 3: Pivot Order Block

Indicator Setup:
Search "Pivot Order Block" in TradingView, add to chart. Access settings via double-click.

Settings Adjustment:
Width change to builties. Box size adjusted to 10 (recommendation). Indicator adds red and green order blocks to EUR/USD chart.

ICT Mapping:
- Pivot points = price memory zones
- Pivots + blocks = institutional reference

09:09 - 13:42 | Backtesting Results & Performance Analysis

Backtesting Procedure:
Uses real database Forex simulator SOFT 4 FX on MetaTrader 4. Initial capital: $110,000. Risk per trade: 2%. EUR/USD backtested on 30-minute timeframe for 6 months. Strategy created as testing tool to determine best indicator through comparison.

Bullish Trading Rules:
Price reaches order block zone and gets rejected. Enter long position at bullish candle closure of recent red candle. Reward-to-risk ratio: 3:1. Stop loss at lowest point of bullish order block zone.

Bearish Trading Rules:
Price touches order block and gets rejected. Enter short position at bearish candle closure of recent green candle. Risk: 2% of capital. Reward-to-risk ratio: 3:1. Stop loss at highest point of order block zone.

Backtesting Results Summary:
Market Structure Break and Order Block Indicator: 112 trades tested, 54% win rate, final capital $2,180. TOP PERFORMER.

Order Block Finder Experimental Indicator: 97 trades tested, 48% win rate, final capital $5,650. SECOND PLACE.

Pivot Order Block Indicator: 105 trades tested, 42% win rate, final capital $122,250. THIRD PLACE.

Key Insights:
Market Structure Break indicator leads in win rate and accuracy. Order Block Finder Experimental shows solid performance. Pivot Order Block indicator generated highest profit despite lower win rate. Strategy designed for basic testing and comparison only. Future episodes will create modified trading strategies for each indicator.

ICT Mapping:
- Indicator accuracy = MSB confidence
- Win rate hierarchy = execution quality
- Backtest validation = strategy confirmation
- Risk management (2% rule) = institutional discipline

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS

- Order block indicators help traders spot institutional accumulation/distribution zones and improve trading success significantly.

- Market Structure Break and Order Block indicator leads with 54% win rate, most accurate for identifying valid order blocks on EUR/USD.

- Order Block Finder Experimental rates second with 48% win rate and $5,650 final capital from 97 trades over 6 months.

- Pivot Order Block indicator ranks third with 42% win rate but generated $122,250 profit, highest profitability despite lower accuracy.

- TradingView setup simple: access indicator tab, search indicator name, add to chart, adjust settings only if needed (defaults recommended).

- Market structure break (MSB) shows bullish when price breaks higher high (green), bearish when breaks lower low (red).

- Order blocks function as supply and demand zones where price expected to reverse direction upon reaching them.

- Backtesting methodology: $110,000 initial capital, 2% risk per trade, 6-month EUR/USD history on 30-minute timeframe.

- Entry rules: wait for price to reject from order block zone, enter at candle closure with 3:1 reward-to-risk ratio.

- Stop loss placement: bullish trades stop at lowest point of order block, bearish trades stop at highest point of zone.

- Indicators work across all timeframes (1 minute to daily), allowing traders to align multiple timeframe orders for confluence.

- Zigzag patterns included in first indicator help identify market structure highs and lows for precise order block placement.

STEP 16: Wait for price to approach bearish order block zone.

STEP 17: Confirm price rejection from bearish order block.

STEP 18: Enter short position at bearish candle closure.

STEP 19: Set stop loss at highest point of order block zone.

STEP 20: Target profit at 3:1 reward-to-risk ratio below entry.

Episode 15: Best Price Action Day Trading Setups to Grow Small Account in 2023



00:00 - 00:59 | Introduction & Overview

Welcome to Smart Risk episode on best price action day trading setups to grow small accounts. Video covers three of the best price action entries that helped grow small accounts when traders first started. First section explains key supply and demand zones for trading based on price action concepts. Second section presents best price action entry strategies found to make money in Forex and stock markets. Subscribe and like if interested in learning advanced trading concepts, strategies, entry reasons, and trading discipline.

ICT Mapping:
- Supply/demand zones = institutional market sentiment identification
- Price action = institutional movement confirmation
- Trading setups = institutional entry/exit methodology
- Small account = retail to institutional transition framework

00:59 - 06:09 | Price Action Concepts & Key Supply-Demand Zones

Supply Zone Definition:
Area above current price where price failed to break through and was rejected multiple times. Market views this area as expensive, causing buyers to close longs and sellers to open shorts. The double action results in price reversal FROM the supply area.

Demand Zone Definition:
Area below current price where price failed to break through and was rejected multiple times. Market views this area as cheap, causing sellers to close shorts and buyers to open longs. The double action results in price reversal FROM the demand area.

Key Supply/Demand Areas:

1. Turning Points (Extreme Levels):
Identified on Aussie Dollar 4-hour timeframe. Market was in long-term downtrend until price reached turning point where trend reversed. Labeled as extreme demand. When price retests this level, provides perfect trading opportunity. Example: New Zealand Dollar 1-hour frame shows continuous uptrend-to-downtrend shifts; turning points regarded as extreme supply and demand levels for best opportunities.

2. Major Levels of Market Structure:
Zone must meet three conditions: rejected multiple times, acted as both support and resistance, recently respected. Produces most accurate trading entries. Example on Pound/Yen daily chart: level rejected multiple times, acted as support/resistance, recently respected. When price taps into level, market expected to reject. Wait for entry reason in lower timeframe.

Example on Aussie Dollar: Multiple conditions line up - major structure level, bearish trendline signaling possible trend change, candlestick strongly rejecting area. Important point: when multiple price action concepts meet in area, optimal chance for high probability entries since many traders focus on same area and take action when opportunities arise.

3. Higher Timeframe Key Levels:
Key levels on lower timeframes often invisible on daily/weekly/monthly frames. Visually obvious levels on higher timeframes extremely important - very high quality, price often reacts. Small reaction on higher timeframes = major reversal opportunity in lower timeframes.

Technique: Label closest levels in front of price as monthly levels. Jump to weekly, adjust monthly levels based on weekly candles, draw new weekly levels if obvious. Jump to daily, adjust monthly and weekly levels based on daily candles. This technique shows bigger picture, identifies major structure levels when trading lower timeframes. When price taps into monthly levels, these are not ordinary supply/demand areas - could be reversal point for short-term trends in lower timeframes.

Important Point: Keep chart as simple as possible. Draw higher timeframe levels only if obvious and helpful for analysis.

ICT Mapping:
- Turning points = institutional pivot zones
- Major structure = institutional acceptance/rejection levels
- Higher timeframe levels = institutional order clusters
- Multiple confluences = institutional liquidity pools

06:09 - 11:43 | Trend Continuation Setups

SETUP 1: Double Top & Double Bottom Rejection Pattern

Definition:
Popular M-shape reversal pattern used by price action traders. Two strict rules for validity:
Rule 1: Wick of lower test must AT LEAST hit body of higher test
Rule 2: Body of higher test must NOT exceed wick of lower test
Same rules apply to double bottom pattern.

Strategy Type: Trend continuation strategy. AVOID using when no obvious trending market present.

Setup Procedure:
Step 1: Identify trend direction
Step 2: Wait for market to make valid double top (uptrend) or valid double bottom (downtrend)
Step 3: Draw line at close of highest candle of pattern
Step 4: Wait for price to touch line
Step 5: Execute trade on confirmation

Entry Confirmation:
Use multiple candlestick formations: long wick rejection or bullish engulfing pattern. Preferred method: enter when candle closes above highest point of previous candle.

Stop Loss & Risk Management:
- Place stop loss 1 ATR below lowest point of rejection
- ATR (Average True Range) = indicator measuring market volatility, gives average size of previous 14 candles in default settings

Example: EUR/USD 1-hour uptrend with higher highs and higher lows (bullish bias). Market made double top and broke upside. Drew line at close of highest candle, waited for price to touch line. Entry: candle close above previous candle's high. Stop loss: 1 ATR below rejection low (12 pips in this case = stop 12 pips below candle low).

Take Profit Targets:
- First TP: Close half position at breakeven once price reaches 1:2 risk-reward target (convert 50% to breakeven trade)
- Second TP: Target next level of structure in front of price

Important Point: Check higher timeframes to determine available room for price movement before reaching next market structure. Example: monthly zone in front could shift pattern to head and shoulders and trigger major trend change.

Bearish Double Bottom Example:
New Zealand Dollar 30-minute timeframe. Downtrend present. Market made double bottom and broke downside. Drew line on close of lowest candle of pattern, waited for price to touch. Opened short position when price printed candle closing below lowest point of previous candle. Stop loss: 1 ATR above highest point of rejection. Target: next demand area.

ICT Mapping:
- Double top/bottom = institutional rejection confirmation
- Valid pattern rules = institutional order flow structure
- ATR-based stops = volatility-adjusted institutional risk
- Higher timeframe checks = institutional order cluster avoidance

SETUP 2: 0.786 Fibonacci Retracement for Trend Continuation

Definition:
Trend continuation setup based on 0.786 Fibonacci retracement level. Best used on pairs with deep retracements (especially gold).

Setup Logic:
In uptrend, market continuously makes higher highs and higher lows. Latest impulsive move starts from point A, ends at point D. Market makes pullback. Question: considering uptrend, what are chances price retests point B before breaking point A and causing major trend change? Answer: chances are pretty high.

Setup Procedure:
Step 1: Confirm obvious uptrend present
Step 2: Apply Fibonacci retracement tool from point A to point B
Step 3: Set buying order precisely on 0.786 level
Step 4: Stop loss couple pips below point A
Step 5: Target point B

Risk-Reward Profile:
Risk-reward ratio = approximately 1:3. Key insight: one winning trade washes away three losing trades. This high R/R ratio makes setup attractive despite potentially lower win rate vs other setups.

Example Application:
Gold 1-hour timeframe showing obvious uptrend with series of impulsive and corrective moves. Applied 0.786 Fibonacci retracement setup showing 1:3 risk-reward ratio potential.

Key Insight:
Trend continuation setups have higher win rates, but for trades with great risk-reward ratios, must trade reversals instead.

ICT Mapping:
- Fibonacci levels = institutional market memory zones
- Deep retracements = institutional accumulation/distribution confirmation
- 0.786 level = probability-weighted institutional entry
- 1:3 ratio = institutional risk management standard

11:43 - 14:29 | Reversal Trading Setup

Reversal Technique:
Combine higher timeframe key levels with reversal patterns for accurate reversal entries. Uses two timeframes: identify major structure level on higher timeframe, then zoom to lower timeframe for pattern confirmation.

Setup Procedure:

Step 1 - Higher Timeframe Analysis:
Identify major level of structure in front of market on higher timeframe. Major level = key level recently acted as both support and resistance multiple times. Expect market to reject this extreme demand area and provide buying opportunity.

Example: EUR/USD 4-hour timeframe in uptrend (bullish bias). Identified major level of structure directly in front of market price.

Step 2 - Lower Timeframe Analysis:
Zoom into one hour timeframe to observe price behavior as it approaches key zone. Wait for specific reversal pattern confirmation.

Step 3 - Pattern Confirmation:
Only need double bottom pattern to signal possible trend change for short-term uptrend. Double bottom shows market failed to create new low, indicating loss of momentum. Signals short-term downtrend over, market can potentially start going upside.

Entry Execution:
Open long position on second test when market prints bullish engulfing candlestick.

Stop Loss & Profit Target:
- Stop loss: 1 ATR below lowest point of swing low
- Profit target: track profit till reaching next level of structure in higher timeframe

Reversal Setup Recap:

1. Identify major level of structure in front of market on higher timeframe
2. Expect market to reject extreme demand area and possibly give buying opportunity
3. Zoom into lower timeframe
4. Look for double bottom reversal pattern
5. Double bottom shows loss of momentum in current downtrend
6. Signals short-term downtrend ending, potential upside move
7. Open buying position with stop below swing low
8. Track profit to next higher timeframe structure level

Key Point: These trading setups not limited to any timeframe or pair. Please do own backtesting to determine which pairs most suitable for these strategies.

Final Takeaway: Subscribe, give thumbs up if enjoyed. Thanks for watching. See you in next episode.

ICT Mapping:
- Multi-timeframe confluence = institutional order alignment
- Major structure in front = institutional stop placement areas
- Double bottom confirmation = momentum loss confirmation
- Swing low stop = institutional support zone targeting

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- Supply zones are expensive areas where price fails to break through multiple times; demand zones are cheap areas with same rejection pattern.

- Market views supply areas as expensive (buyers exit longs, sellers open shorts), demand areas as cheap (sellers exit shorts, buyers open longs).

- Turning points represent extreme supply and demand levels where market identifies area as very expensive or very cheap.

- Major levels of market structure require three conditions: rejected multiple times, acted as both support and resistance, and recently respected.

- Higher timeframe levels (monthly, weekly, daily) are extremely important and often invisible on lower timeframes.

- Technique for multi-timeframe analysis: label levels as monthly, adjust on weekly, adjust again on daily to see bigger picture.

- Double top/bottom rejection pattern has two strict validity rules: lower test wick must hit higher body, higher body must not exceed lower wick.

- Double top/bottom is trend continuation setup only - avoid using in choppy, non-trending markets.

- Entry confirmation uses candlestick formations like long wick rejection or bullish engulfing pattern.

- Stop loss placement: 1 ATR below lowest point of rejection candle (ATR measures market volatility).

- First take profit: close 50% of position at breakeven once hitting 1:2 target; second take profit at next structure level.

- Check higher timeframes before entering to know how much room price has until next market structure (avoid head and shoulders trap).

- 0.786 Fibonacci retracement setup best for pairs with deep retracements like gold; applies to strong uptrends.

- 0.786 Fibonacci setup uses A-to-B retracement, buy order at 0.786 level, stop couple pips below A, target point B.

- Risk-reward ratio for Fibonacci setup approximately 1:3, allowing one winning trade to offset three losing trades.

- Trend continuation setups have higher win rates but lower risk-reward ratios.

- Reversal setups require higher timeframe major structure identification plus lower timeframe pattern confirmation.

- Reversal setup example: identify major structure on 4-hour, zoom to 1-hour, confirm with double bottom pattern.

- Double bottom in reversal shows loss of momentum and signals short-term downtrend ending.

- Entry for reversal: open long on second test when bullish engulfing candle prints.

- Stop loss for reversal: 1 ATR below swing low; profit target: next structure level in higher timeframe.

- All setups not limited to any timeframe or currency pair; backtest for pair-specific optimization.



================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: Analyze market for supply and demand zones
STEP 2: Identify turning points where major reversals occurred
STEP 3: Mark major levels of structure meeting three conditions (rejected multiple times, support/resistance, recently respected)
STEP 4: Check higher timeframes (monthly/weekly/daily) for confluent levels
STEP 5: Apply multi-timeframe technique - label monthly levels, adjust on weekly, re-adjust on daily
STEP 6: Determine if market is trending (obvious higher highs/lows or lower lows/highs)
STEP 7: For trend continuation - scan for double top/bottom pattern with strict wick/body rules
STEP 8: Apply Fibonacci retracement from A to B for deep pullback plays
STEP 9: For reversals - identify major structure on higher timeframe in front of price
STEP 10: Zoom to lower timeframe to observe price behavior as it approaches key zone
STEP 11: Confirm double bottom pattern forms in lower timeframe
STEP 12: Wait for bullish engulfing candle on second test as entry signal
STEP 13: Calculate ATR for volatility-adjusted stop loss placement
STEP 14: Place stop 1 ATR below lowest point of rejection or swing low
STEP 15: Set first take profit at 1:2 risk-reward by closing 50% position
STEP 16: Set second take profit at next market structure level
STEP 17: Check higher timeframes to ensure no monthly/weekly zones blocking path
STEP 18: Journal trade entry, structure details, and outcome
STEP 19: Backtest setups on multiple pairs to optimize for pair-specific behavior
STEP 20: Document win rate and risk-reward outcomes over time

02:00 - 05:10 | Entry Signals, Baseline Colors, and Trade Rules

Trend Checker A signals: Buy signal = markup phase (price goes higher), Sell signal = markdown phase (price goes lower). Baseline colors: Green = bullish market, Red = bearish market. Yellow diamonds indicate sudden volume changes. White EMA line acts as dynamic support/resistance. Blue/red arrows show take-profit signals.

Long Trade Rules: After buy signal, validate with green baseline and price above EMA (bullish short-term trend). Enter long with stop loss below recent swing low, target 1.5x risk. Short Trade Rules: After sell signal, validate with red baseline and price below EMA (bearish short-term trend). Enter short with stop loss above recent swing high, target 1.5x risk.

ICT Mapping:
- Markup phase = institutional accumulation
- Markdown phase = institutional distribution
- EMA validation = institutional level confirmation

Ethereum/Dollar Example: Buy signal, price above EMA, green baseline - long position with stop below swing low and 1.5x risk-reward ratio.

08:00 - 10:20 | Using Trend Checker B Divergence for Entry Confirmation

Divergence Types: Bearish divergence = price makes higher highs but Trend Checker B makes lower highs (trend weakening). Bullish divergence = price makes lower lows but Trend Checker B makes higher lows (reversal signal).

New Zealand Dollar Example: Buy signal, green baseline, price making lower lows but TCB making higher lows (bullish divergence) - enter long with stop below swing low.

Secondary Example: Sell signal, red baseline, price making higher highs but TCB making lower highs (bearish divergence) - enter short with stop above swing high, 1.5x risk-reward.

ICT Mapping:
- Bullish divergence = institutional buying at support
- Bearish divergence = institutional selling at resistance
- Volume divergence = institutional momentum loss

10:20 - 11:30 | Advanced Profit Tracking Strategy Using Divergence

Bitcoin Example: Buy signal, bullish divergence detected. Instead of fixed take-profit, track profit by moving stop loss to breakeven at each higher low. Continue trailing stops until higher timeframe supply zone reached. Maximizes profit potential by risking same amount.

Ethereum Example: Sell signal, bearish divergence. Track profit by moving stop below each lower high until reaching HTF supply zone.

ICT Mapping:
- Trailing stop management = institutional momentum continuation
- HTF supply zones = institutional profit targets
- Higher low/high tracking = institutional swing identification

- Short entry rules: Validate sell signal with red baseline + price below EMA, enter at candle close, stop above swing high, target 1.5x risk.

- Bearish divergence occurs when price makes higher highs but Trend Checker B makes lower highs (confirmation for short entries).

================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: Open TradingView with desired trading pair (EUR/USD, crypto, stocks, etc.).

STEP 2: Access indicator tab and search for "Trend Checker A and B" in invite-only scripts.

STEP 3: Add both Trend Checker A and B to chart (A on chart, B below chart).

STEP 4: Go to Trend Checker A settings, uncheck SSL line and candle size exit arrows.

STEP 5: Change moving average color to white in style tab for chart clarity.

STEP 6: Monitor Trend Checker A for buy signals (markup phase = price goes higher).

STEP 7: When buy signal appears, check if baseline color is GREEN.

STEP 8: Verify price is sitting ABOVE the white EMA line.

STEP 9: Check Trend Checker B for bullish divergence (price lower low, TCB higher low).

STEP 10: If all conditions met, enter LONG position at green candle close.

STEP 11: Place stop loss BELOW the most recent swing low.

STEP 12: Set take-profit target at 1.5x the risk amount above entry.

STEP 13: Monitor Trend Checker A for sell signals (markdown phase = price goes lower).

STEP 14: When sell signal appears, check if baseline color is RED.

STEP 15: Verify price is sitting BELOW the white EMA line.

STEP 16: Check Trend Checker B for bearish divergence (price higher high, TCB lower high).

STEP 17: If all conditions met, enter SHORT position at red candle close.

STEP 18: Place stop loss ABOVE the most recent swing high.

STEP 19: Set take-profit target at 1.5x the risk amount below entry.

STEP 20: For advanced strategy, trail stop to each higher low (long) or lower high (short) until supply zone reached.

================================================================================
TRADING CHECKLISTS
================================================================================

A. INDICATOR SETUP & CONFIGURATION

- [ ] TradingView platform open
- [ ] Desired trading pair loaded (EUR/USD, BTC, ETH, etc.)
- [ ] Indicator tab accessed
- [ ] Trend Checker A added to chart
- [ ] Trend Checker B added below chart
- [ ] Settings: SSL line unchecked
- [ ] Settings: Candle size exit arrows unchecked
- [ ] Settings: Moving average color changed to white
- [ ] Baseline color indicator visible (green/red)
- [ ] Yellow diamonds visible for volume spikes

B. BULLISH SIGNAL & LONG ENTRY CONFIRMATION

- [ ] Trend Checker A shows buy signal (markup phase)
- [ ] Baseline color is GREEN (bullish)
- [ ] Price is sitting ABOVE white EMA line
- [ ] Trend Checker B shows bullish divergence (price LL, TCB HL)
- [ ] All conditions confirmed simultaneously
- [ ] Green candle closure identified for entry
- [ ] Entry price calculated
- [ ] 1.5x risk-to-reward ratio calculated
- [ ] Swing low identified for stop loss placement
- [ ] Long position ready for execution

C. BEARISH SIGNAL & SHORT ENTRY CONFIRMATION

- [ ] Trend Checker A shows sell signal (markdown phase)
- [ ] Baseline color is RED (bearish)
- [ ] Price is sitting BELOW white EMA line
- [ ] Trend Checker B shows bearish divergence (price HH, TCB LH)
- [ ] All conditions confirmed simultaneously
- [ ] Red candle closure identified for entry
- [ ] Entry price calculated
- [ ] 1.5x risk-to-reward ratio calculated
- [ ] Swing high identified for stop loss placement
- [ ] Short position ready for execution

D. PROFIT TRACKING & ADVANCED MANAGEMENT

- [ ] Position entered with divergence confirmation
- [ ] Initial stop loss set (below swing low for long, above swing high for short)
- [ ] Take-profit target set at 1.5x risk
- [ ] Price moving in position favor monitored
- [ ] Higher low identified (long) or lower high identified (short)
- [ ] Stop loss moved to new higher low (long) or lower high (short)
- [ ] Higher timeframe supply/demand zone identified
- [ ] Trailing stops continued until HTF zone reached
- [ ] Final profit captured at HTF zone or signal reversal
- [ ] Trade journaled with all key levels and outcomes

Episode 17: Inducement & Liquidity - How Market Makers Trap Retail Traders


================================================================================

00:00 - 00:37 | Introduction & Critical Problem Statement

The episode opens with a foundational question for traders: if you fail with smart money concepts and price action without understanding the reason, then you don't know the secrets behind inducement and liquidity. Liquidity and inducement are positioned as two of the most critical concepts of smart money that every trader must master before placing any trade. This episode reveals the secrets behind inducement and liquidity traps and teaches how to avoid getting caught in the liquidity and inducement traps that market makers always have prepared for retail traders. The call-to-action encourages engagement with the channel for this educational content.

ICT Mapping:
- Inducement & liquidity = institutional trap mechanics
- Market maker manipulation = why retail traders consistently fail
- Trap identification = foundational survival skill

00:37 - 01:47 | Inducement Definition & Institutional Purpose

Welcome back traders. Before explaining the manipulation methods and traps that central banks and large financial institutions have prepared for traders, traders should be able to detect the possible inducement and liquidity zones in the market and know their exact definitions. Inducement occurs at a specific point or zone in the market where traders believe it is the correct time to enter a trade based on their analysis and trading system. This is precisely the tool used by central banks and large financial institutions to fall retail traders into their traps.

Inducements appear at four specific points and zones: order blocks, support and resistance levels, swing highs and swing lows, and trend lines. Order blocks are very important optimized supply and demand zones that when price reaches them may potentially change direction to the opposite way. Order blocks include many buy and sell orders, making them inducement levels where traders get induced into the market and always place their buy or sell orders to get taken into the market.

Example Order Blocks: Price breaks the recent market structure to the upside and generated this bullish order block where traders looking to have long positions by setting their buy orders because it's an area where induced traders get into the market. Its obvious price did not respect this bullish order block so this order block is not valid and fails the SMC traders so we call it an inducement. Again we have another order block a little bit lower as you can see guys price did not respect this order block so it is not valid so it's an inducement like the first order block. Be sure to watch this video until the end because it shows which order block is valid and safe to trade and which one is an inducement that you must ignore.

ICT Mapping:
- Order block inducement = institutional deception level
- Invalid order blocks = predictable stop hunt zones
- Valid vs inducement identification = professional skill

01:47 - 03:01 | Support/Resistance & Swing High/Low Inducements

The next zones where inducement occurs oftentimes are support and resistance levels. All traders consider support and resistance as levels that price will change its direction and will respect these levels every time price comes back to them so many traders always get induced into the market in these zones.

For example we have this major support zone that price is rejected from it multiple times so traders get induced into market every time price comes back into this area by hoping that price pushes to the upside they set thereby orders at this area and finally get induced into market. But as you can see price before going to the upside went down and hit the stop loss of the traders by this long wick who had buy position in the support level. Price after taking out the buyers rapidly started to rise up so guys this is an inducement and this scenario has been designed by market makers.

Swing lows and highs are the points on the chart that might behave as inducements. Swing highs and swing lows are the highest and lowest points where price has recently hit especially on higher time frames like daily these points are more important and price has more tendency to respect these points so traders always get induced into the market in swing highs and swing lows.

For example here an NCD dollar daily time frame we have this swing high as the highest point that price has recently hit and we spot this point as the swing low. Most of the retail traders place their buy and sell orders at swing low and swing high with the argument that price will respect these areas and will change its direction when reaches them. As you can see price makes fake breakouts in these areas and hit the stop loss of both buyers and sellers so guys we consider them as inducements.

ICT Mapping:
- Support/resistance inducement = false reversal belief
- Swing high/low traps = mechanical stop hunting
- Fake breakouts = institutional liquidity collection

03:01 - 03:51 | Trend Line Inducement & Using Inducement as Advantage

Trend line is the fourth item that frequently acts as an inducement. The trend line is a line drawn over pivot highs or under pivot lows to show the prevailing direction of price. Trend lines are a visual representation of support and resistance in any time frame. Most of the retail traders consider trend lines as their possible entry points and get induced into the market when price breaks or reaches the current trend line of the market.

For example here we have this trend line that price touched it two times so retail traders would get induced and take short position after price respected trend line at the third touch or if price does not respect the trend line it would look for a long position because the price breaks the trend line and they think it's the right time to place an order and get into the market. This scenario is happening over and over in the market traders always see something on the price chart and they place orders based on their analysis and trading plans because they think it's the right time to take positions in the market.

How may inducement be advantageous for us? Inducement can be used to identify the market liquidity zones. Additionally it enables us to move with market liquidity and take profits instead of getting trapped in the liquidity of the market's major players.

ICT Mapping:
- Trend line inducement = visual false signal
- Inducement advantage = liquidity zone identification
- Pattern recognition = professional trader edge

03:51 - 08:32 | Liquidity Definition & Locations

Now we know the basics of inducement let's move on to liquidity. What is the exact definition of liquidity? Liquidity simply means money or large counter orders that must be fulfilled. Market always needs to sweep the liquidity to gain momentum in other words liquidity is used as the fuel of the market which is vital and necessary for the market dynamics.

So where we can find the liquidity? Liquidity is a zone on the chart where a large pool of money is resting such as stop losses and buy or sell orders because when somebody gets stopped out of a position that money gets taken by the market. So this is a scenario designed by central banks or big financial institutions they artificially manipulate the market and make traders believe that they know what is going on with price action and essentially most of the time those people are wrong and they fall into the traps and finally they lost their capital.

So if we want to survive in the financial markets as a profitable trader and prevent huge losses we must be able to properly identify the liquidity zones on the chart. We already can find liquidity below equal lows and swing low, above equal highs swing highs, below or above the dynamic trend lines or channels, and below or above order blocks.

Now we know the basic of liquidity and inducement so what is the difference between liquidity and inducement? Liquidity doesn't take traders into the market it takes them out of the market but inducement forces traders to get into the market and eventually get caught by the traps that market makers already designed for them. We already discuss both inducement and liquidity and now we have important information about them in the following I am going to show you how to use inducement and liquidity in your trading plan to avoid getting trapped by market makers and reduce your potential losses.

ICT Mapping:
- Liquidity = institutional exit mechanism
- Market maker design = stop loss collection
- Trader survival = liquidity and inducement mastery
- Inducement vs Liquidity = opposite mechanics

08:32 - 11:19 | First Schematic Example: Unmitigated Zones & Liquidity Sweep

So here we have the schematic figure that simulates the price movements. As you can see we have a downtrend price mitigates this zone here then reverse to the downside. As you can see price is pushed to the downside and couldn't break the recent structure also price makes this tiny pullback to the upside.

After gaining enough momentum price is pushed to the downside and has made this break of structure here. So guys we have this unmitigated zone here that potentially price may get reversed from it also we have another unmitigated zone right here which is created by the recent BOS. So most of the smart money concept traders ICT traders and retail traders get confused and they don't really know which zone is more safe to trade.

As we have explained before inducements are places on the chart designed by big smart money concepts traders like central banks or large financial institutions to deceive or induce retail traders to have buy or sell positions in the market and eventually build more liquidity for them. So for us this zone is an inducement level because as you can see here price tried to mitigate the upper zone but instead before reaching this zone it went down rapidly and broke the recent structure to the downside.

So what we will see in the cases like this scenario that is the market makers induce some of the SMC ICT and retail traders to get into the market and have cell positions when price mitigating this inducement zone. In the continue as you can see price rose up and touched the inducement zone and shows us a little rejection from the zone so this rejection makes most of the traders excited and makes them believe that price will go in their direction. Also this rejection induces more price action traders to get into the market by opening sell positions within the stop losses above this double top.

Now guys as you can see here this scenario which is designed by market makers has generated massive liquidity here right below our first unmitigated zone so as you know guys the market always sweeps the liquidity to gain its momentum so here price come back to our first unmitigated zone swept the liquidity and continued to its primary direction I mean downside. So guys this was a simplified scenario that shows how market makers and central banks manipulate the market to fall retail traders into traps get them out of the market and take their capital.

ICT Mapping:
- Schematic inducement = institutional deception pattern
- Double top = inducement signature
- Liquidity sweep = predictable institutional mechanics
- Unmitigated zones = actual reversal opportunities

11:19 - 17:09 | Second & Third Schematic Examples: Complex Manipulation Patterns

After this pullback price went down and generated this break of structure also we can easily spot this unmitigated zone here and we have this double top here we know that this double top created a very good liquidity zone which rests right above the equal highs and we know that finally price will come for sweeping liquidity gathered here to mitigate this order block.

Also the double top acted as a resistance level and retail traders entered the market by going short from it and expecting price to push lower to the downside. In the continue we expect that price sweep the liquidity resting above equal highs but we see price didn't sweep the liquidity and continued to the downside after mitigating this zone.

By happening this scenario most of the traders are getting confused and asking questions like why prices move to the downside without sweeping the liquidity resting over the equal highs. Guys we don't exactly know what price will do or when price will come back and sweep the liquidity that is resting in the market. It probably can take an hour or a month but price definitely will sweep the resting liquidity the only thing that we should do certainly is to avoid trading from areas like this area that liquidity pool is resting above it because definitely price in the future will come after the liquidity pool.

So guys let's continue as you can see price after reaching this zone here pushed to the downside and already generated this break of structure here. So guys for me this unmitigated order block which is created by the last BOS is an inducement level that market makers waiting for it because this zone looks like a very good cell zone for the SMC and ICT traders which is created from a break of structure with some imbalances appeared in its movement to the downside.

Market makers know this fact that most of the SMC and ICT traders have their eyes on this level and they will get into the market by short positions but in fact they already forgot about the liquidity pool resting above the zone and also they forgot about this unmitigated zone here. As you can see we already have this trend line that when price touches it most of the retail traders and price action traders will get into the market by sell positions so this trend line is created good liquidity at the top of its line.

So guys this inducement level provides a lot of rational reasons that SMC ICT and retail traders would think this level is a very good zone for selling the market and market makers already know this. Market makers already know the trading setups and thoughts of the retail traders and they always prepare traps to get retail traders into the market and take their capital.

So guys as I mentioned before we consider this zone as an inducement and definitely we are not going to get into the market in this zone. As you can see price after showing tiny respect for the inducement zone went up rapidly and mitigated this zone and swept the liquidity that accumulated for a long time and already swept the liquidity that recently created by the stop losses of the traders who sold the market from inducement level. As you can see price finally pushed lower and continued in its primary direction.

So guys let's see another possible scenario that frequently would happen in the market. So as you can see on the left side price is in a downtrend and respected this channel multiple times. As you can see price after making this lower low and mitigating this important bullish order block has changed its direction to upward for touching the top line of the channel. We can consider this area as an inducement level.

So it is obvious most of the retail traders who trade based on chart patterns will get into the market by sell orders at this point where price touches the channel's top line and they also create this liquidity pool by setting their stop losses here. So as you know guys market makers always want to sweep the liquidity of the market so in this scenario they pushed price to the upside and as you can see price broke this structure and also broke the channel to the upside and hit the stop losses of retail traders and gain more momentum.

In the continue by breaking the channel's trend line most of the retail traders aggressively get into the market by opening long positions so guys here traders are induced to get into the market by both cells and buys positions. This scenario happens over and over in the market and this is exactly is what market makers want.

In the following some traders enter by positions at this pullback and expect price to go higher as you can see price continue to the upside and also made this temporary trend line then what happened as you can see price pushed higher and suddenly dropped to sweep the liquidity pool resting here which made with the stop losses of retail traders who entered to buy positions within the temporary uptrend.

In the following price after collecting liquidity of both buyers and sellers and after mitigating this extreme demand zone pushed to the upward.

ICT Mapping:

The lucky traders who had short positions from here looked to find an opportunity to enter a short position from this order block that is generated by recent BOS but this level is an inducement level because based on smart money basics this zone seems a very good and safe level to go short because first it's an unmitigated order block and second the price already has reversed from this zone in the recent past.

Many SMC traders who did not understand the liquidity and inducement topics they get induced into the market and place their sell orders in this area and they also disregard the liquidity zones that are resting on the chart.
