TRADING CHECKLISTS
================================================================================

A. PULLBACK IDENTIFICATION AND VALIDATION

- [ ] Identify prevailing trend direction (bullish or bearish) on current timeframe
- [ ] Recognize temporary reversal or pause in price action against trend
- [ ] Observe buyers and sellers contention for market dominance
- [ ] Identify impulsive movement creating internal liquidity (inefficiency or static)
- [ ] Confirm price experiences reversal and brief interruption against dominant trend
- [ ] Verify internal liquidity or static liquidity being filled or cleared
- [ ] Confirm price movement consists of impulse, corrective, continuation submovements
- [ ] Bullish scenario: candle breaks below lowest point of previous candle
- [ ] Bearish scenario: candle breaks above highest point of previous candles
- [ ] Verify candlestick color does not affect pullback identification validity
- [ ] Confirm pullback qualifies as valid using mechanical criteria established
- [ ] Invalid pullback identified leads to order block validity loss recognition

B. CANDLESTICK UPTREND AND DOWNTREND ANALYSIS

- [ ] Bullish uptrend: consecutive bullish candles each exceeding highest point previous
- [ ] Bullish uptrend: lowest point each candle equal/higher than previous candles
- [ ] Bearish momentum restricted in bullish uptrend indicating trend strength
- [ ] Overall trend remains predominantly bullish when conditions met
- [ ] Bearish downtrend: consecutive bearish candles each exceeding lowest point previous
- [ ] Bearish downtrend: highest point each candle equal/lower than previous candles
- [ ] Bullish momentum restricted in bearish downtrend indicating trend strength
- [ ] Bullish single impulse move: no bearish candle breaks lowest preceding bullish
- [ ] Equal high formation with previous candle noted for subsequent break analysis
- [ ] Subsequent candle breaks and sweeps below low qualifying valid pullback
- [ ] Principles applicable across various timeframes verified
- [ ] Price action-based chart analysis compatible with criteria confirmed

C. THREE PULLBACK MODEL CATEGORIZATION AND RESPONSE

- [ ] Aggressive pullback: rapid sharp retracement with large strong candles
- [ ] Aggressive pullback: price quickly retraces portion of recent movement
- [ ] Aggressive pullback: avoid entry even with confirmation patterns present
- [ ] Aggressive pullback: price moves into zone without subsiding momentum
- [ ] Aggressive pullback: high probability zone will not react to price
- [ ] Corrective pullback: more gradual retracement with multiple smaller candles
- [ ] Corrective pullback: price generates several internal structures approaching zone
- [ ] Corrective pullback: momentum and volatility subside approaching point of interest
- [ ] Corrective pullback: consider entering market when price reaches identified zone
- [ ] Sweeping pullback: price generates liquidity pools near point of interest
- [ ] Sweeping pullback: equal highs, equal lows, or trendline liquidity formation
- [ ] Sweeping pullback: liquidity sweep pattern recognition confirms area strength

D. ENTRY EXECUTION AND RISK MANAGEMENT

- [ ] Valid break of structure confirmed with valid pullback formation
- [ ] Demand or supply zone identified attributed to break of structure
- [ ] Zone believed has high potential to reverse price when reached
- [ ] Back-testing: strategy tested at least 100 times before real account application
- [ ] Aggressive entry model: buy limit order placed at highest point order block
- [ ] Conservative entry model: wait for tap then zoom lower timeframe confirmation
- [ ] Lower timeframe: search for change of character or reversal patterns
- [ ] Market structure shift confirmation detected on entry timeframe
- [ ] Entry position set on highest point newly recognized order block lower timeframe
- [ ] Stop-loss set few pips above lowest point of demand zone
- [ ] Take profit set at external liquidity of higher timeframe
- [ ] Entry point optimized for better reward-to-risk ratio with tighter stop-loss
- [ ] Newly generated demand zone on lower timeframe created by change of character wave
- [ ] Liquidity sweep below equal lows waited for before entry trigger
- [ ] Desired confluence achieved with multiple confirmation factors aligned

Episode 55: Simplifying Key Order Blocks in Forex Trading



[00:00] - [01:05] | Introduction: Learning from Trading Mistakes and Order Blocks

The episode opens by establishing a fundamental principle of trading: when trading in the financial markets, traders are going to make a lot of mistakes, and learning nothing from those mistakes is the actual mistake. After numerous trades on multiple pairs, it became evident to the presenter that order blocks operate more effectively and generate profits when they are accompanied by certain conditions. This observation forms the foundation for the entire episode's teaching. The presenter promises to simplify the concept of order blocks in trading by explaining a rule-based approach toward the order blocks that are being respected by the market. The episode will explain what conditions are required for a valid order block, how to effectively mark and trade them on the chart, and also the internal and external market structure concepts that are required to combine with the order block concept. This comprehensive framework sets up the systematic approach to order block trading that will be developed throughout the episode.

ICT Mapping:
- Learning from mistakes = institutional trader development and pattern recognition
- Conditions with order blocks = institutional confluence factors for valid setups
- Rule-based approach = institutional mechanical trading system development
- Market-respected blocks = institutional order flow alignment and execution zones

[01:05] - [02:13] | Understanding Order Blocks: Definition and Distinction from Supply/Demand

The presenter welcomes traders back and establishes the definition: generally, order blocks are areas where the buying or selling orders reside. The market has rejected these levels once, so when it returns to these levels, it might react to them again. A critical distinction is established: every order block is a supply or demand level, but not every supply and demand area qualifies as an order block. This distinction is crucial for traders to understand. Every reaction to a price level creates a supply or demand area, showing that for whatever reason, traders have opened massive buy or sell positions which cause significant price movements. When price returns to these levels, traders closely monitor the price action to find possible trading opportunities.

However, trading every supply and demand area would not be effective. Through time and witnessing repetitive patterns on the chart, traders have noticed that when supply and demand areas are accompanied by certain conditions, the chance of working significantly improves. One of the key supply and demand areas is order blocks. This establishes why identifying conditions becomes critical for separating high-probability order blocks from low-probability supply and demand areas. The first step is understanding what conditions are required to consider an area as a valid order block to trade, which will then guide how to effectively mark them on the chart.

ICT Mapping:
- Order blocks = institutional supply/demand zones with prior market rejection
- Massive buy/sell positions = institutional order clustering and momentum creation
- Market returns to levels = institutional trapped liquidity reactivation
- Condition-based filtering = institutional confluence validation for high-probability zones

[02:13] - [03:06] | Rule 1: Inefficiency as Valid Order Block Foundation

The presenter establishes the first rule for valid order blocks: having inefficiency. Inefficiency, imbalance, and fair value gaps are highly similar concepts that traders use interchangeably. When a large amount of money enters the market and creates an imbalance between the buyers and sellers, fair value gap patterns form between the candles, creating a phase of inefficiency. These movements on the chart show that smart money has entered the market and affected the price. The institutional significance is that price often returns to these areas to accumulate the remaining orders, which creates a trading opportunity. The price takes off after reaching order blocks but only if there exist remaining orders to be filled.

Therefore, a supply or demand area that created fair value gaps becomes a strong level that traders should prioritize. The mechanical rule traders apply: always mark the fair value gaps on the chart when mapping the market structure, as this is the first rule of identifying a valid order block. The inefficiency indicates institutional money has moved through the market, leaving a vacuum that price returns to fill. Understanding this dynamic explains why order blocks with inefficiency markers have higher success rates than unmarked supply and demand areas without institutional activity indicators.

ICT Mapping:
- Inefficiency and imbalance = institutional order flow distortion creating fair value gaps
- Fair value gaps = institutional supply/demand zone markers showing smart money activity
- Remaining orders accumulation = institutional liquidity pool location and refueling
- Price takeoff after order blocks = institutional momentum generation from accumulated liquidity

[03:06] - [04:27] | Rule 2: Breaking Market Structure as Order Block Validation

The second rule for having a valid order block is breaking the market structure. In the bullish scenario, when a price movement breaks the latest market structure and closes above the recent high, the origin of the price movement becomes highly important. This origin point shows that the demand area that created this movement is not an ordinary level but an influential area in the market structure. With all being said, a supply or demand zone is considered a valid order block that leads to a structural break. The significance lies in understanding that the origin of the impulsive move carries more weight than subsequent corrections.

The same concept applies to the bearish scenario. When a price movement breaks the latest market structure to the downside, the origin of the price movement becomes highly important. It shows that the supply area that created this movement is not an ordinary level but an influential zone in the market structure. These demand areas are considered valid order blocks. In a moving uptrend example, the most recent break of structure shows that the demand is still in control, and all the demand areas along the way are considered opportunities. However, the origin of the bullish price movement is highly important and provides the best trading opportunities. There is a high chance that the rest become victims of liquidity grabs, which is why traders have to use lower risk when placing trades in these subsequent areas. The institutional principle: the first block creating the break carries institutional power; later blocks may become traps.

ICT Mapping:
- Breaking market structure = institutional structural momentum confirmation requirement
- Origin of price movement = institutional impulsive wave source with highest probability
- Influential area identification = institutional order block strength assessment
- First break highest probability = institutional institutional entry priority in trend

[04:27] - [05:16] | Liquidity Concepts: Stop-Loss Locations and Liquidity Grab Patterns

The presenter emphasizes a crucial element: liquidity. Liquidity is where the stop losses reside. This simple statement carries profound meaning: identifying where institutional stop-losses cluster determines where price will hunt for liquidity. Combining the liquidity concept with order blocks enhances understanding of market dynamics and provides valuable information for strategic decision-making. Grabbing liquidity in the direction of the current trend before reaching a supply and demand area improves the quality of that area. This principle explains why price often moves past initial order blocks—it's hunting for stop-loss liquidity before respecting the order block.

There are three common liquidity grab patterns that happen every day on the chart. Forming each one before reaching the order block increases the chance of success for the trade. This is why traders who understand liquidity dynamics have higher success rates with order block trading. The three patterns provide mechanical ways to identify when price is likely moving to collect stops rather than reversing, versus when it's ready to establish a reversal from the order block. Understanding these patterns allows traders to distinguish between false order block reactions and genuine institutional setups, improving trade accuracy and reducing false breakout trades.

ICT Mapping:
- Liquidity locations = institutional stop-loss clustering zones for predatory sweep
- Liquidity grabs in trend direction = institutional momentum continuation before correction
- Three patterns repetition = institutional mechanical price action sequence on charts
- Liquidity grab before order block = institutional setup confirmation and zone strength validation

[05:16] - [06:41] | Liquidity Grab Pattern 1: Fair Value Gaps Below Order Blocks

The first liquidity grab pattern involves fair value gaps with an order block zone precisely below the demand area. There is a high chance that the first demand area becomes the victim of a liquidity grab movement, and then price takes off when it reaches the order block zone. This will make the order block zone even more powerful because the market now contains the required liquidity for future movements. In a practical example, traders have a demand area and a potential trading opportunity to go long. Looking at the left side, traders can spot a gap between the candles precisely below the demand zone. This gap will act as a magnet for price to come and fill it, restore the balance, grab the liquidity, and continue pushing upwards when it mitigates the order block.

A critical practical point emerges: before placing any trade, traders should look at the left side to see the market structure conditions to avoid unnecessary risk. When this kind of scenario forms on the chart, there's a higher chance for the move to be just a liquidity grab and does not necessarily mean a reversal is coming, making the order block zone more powerful and a perfect trading opportunity to go long. The institutional logic: when gap exists below the demand zone, price must first fill it (grabbing stop-loss liquidity) before the real reversal from the order block occurs. Traders who trade the immediate first reaction often get stopped out at the gap; those waiting for the gap fill get a cleaner entry.

ICT Mapping:
- Fair value gaps = institutional liquidity magnet and stop-loss location marker
- Gap filling requirement = institutional gap-fill algorithm before true reversal
- Order block power increase = institutional confluence from gap fill before structural support
- Left-side market structure = institutional context validation for entry quality

[06:41] - [07:51] | Liquidity Grab Pattern 2: Equal Highs and Lows Strategy

The second liquidity grab pattern happens by forming equal highs and lows. Equal highs and lows are interesting trading areas for traditional support and resistance traders because they represent previous price levels. In the bullish scenario, below the equal lows contain lots of liquidity from accumulated stop-losses. If the correction move consists of this kind of support area, this is another confirmation that the conditions are ready for smart money to grab the liquidity and continue pushing forward when price reaches the demand zone. The equal low becomes a stop-loss magnet that price hunts before respecting the order block above.

The same concept applies to the bearish scenario. Above the equal highs contain lots of liquidity. If the correction move consists of this kind of resistance area, this is another confirmation that the conditions are ready for smart money to grab the liquidity and continue pushing downwards when price reaches the supply zone. The mechanical validation traders use: if a correction move retraces to an equal high or equal low level, and that level contains an order block above or below, the probability of price making a liquidity grab at the equal level increases substantially. This pattern explains why price often retests exact previous levels before moving in the direction of the order block. The institutional algorithm: retrace to equal level, hunt stop-losses, then continue in order block direction.

ICT Mapping:
- Equal highs and lows = institutional previous price level liquidity markers
- Below equal lows liquidity = institutional stop-loss cluster from failed shorts
- Above equal highs liquidity = institutional stop-loss cluster from failed longs
- Liquidity grab before order block = institutional mechanical sweep confirmation pattern

[07:51] - [08:48] | Marking Order Blocks: Candlestick Selection and Basic Methodology

Now the presenter shows how to effectively mark order blocks on the chart. Traders mark the last candlestick before the start of a drastic bullish move as the order block zone. Regardless of the candle color, traders believe that the decisions are made during this candle, which makes it an important area where the buying orders reside. When price taps into this area again, traders will open a buy position and set the stop below the zone. In some cases, traders even look for more confirmations and entry setups in the lower timeframes, which will be discussed in future videos.

The same concept applies to the bearish scenario. Traders mark the last candlestick before the start of a drastic bearish move as the order block zone. This is the basic form of marking the order blocks on the chart, providing a mechanical starting point for traders. The principle is universal: identify the final consolidation candle before the impulsive move, mark it as the order block, and watch for price return to that zone. The institutional significance: that final candle contains the institutional order clustering point where smart money accumulated positions before the directional move. Marking it correctly becomes the foundation for all subsequent order block trading decisions.

ICT Mapping:
- Last candle before move = institutional decision point and order accumulation zone
- Candle color irrelevance = institutional orders exist regardless of close direction
- Buying orders residence = institutional demand level marking methodology
- Stop placement below zone = institutional stop-loss location setting convention

[08:48] - [09:49] | Order Block Marking Adjustments: Wick Inclusion and Size Considerations

In some scenarios, traders must make adjustments to basic order block marking. Sometimes a wick grabs the liquidity below the order block candlestick, which makes traders add this wick to their zone. But the problem is traders would have a large order block to trade. That's why in situations like this, traders will look for more confirmations in the lower timeframes to execute trades at a better price. This adjustment reflects the reality that institutional stop-losses may extend below the candlestick body.

Sometimes the candlestick that created the order block is a very small one. There is a chance that price will mitigate this zone and respect the low, but it is not a law. If traders trade this on the real chart, they will notice that many times the market will break through these areas before starting to push upwards. So in situations where the order block contains a small area, traders will set a large stop-loss below the order block or consider a larger area on both sides. But how do traders know that this candle is smaller than the average candlestick range? They measure it by applying the ATR indicator on the chart. The Average True Range (ATR) is an indicator that measures market volatility. It gives the average size of the previous 14 candles in default settings.

ICT Mapping:
- Wick grabbing liquidity = institutional extended stop-loss levels requiring zone expansion
- Large zone problem = institutional risk management requiring lower timeframe confirmation
- Small candlestick marking = institutional momentum continuation requiring stop-loss extension
- ATR measurement = institutional volatility-based zone sizing methodology

[09:49] - [10:35] | ATR Rule: Extending Order Blocks Below 60% of Average Volatility

An extra rule emerges for marking the order block zone: if the order block candlestick is smaller than 60% of the ATR, traders will extend the zone to one ATR from both sides. For example, if the ATR shows that the average size of the past 14 candles is 20 pips, and the order block range is lower than 60% of 20 (which is 12 pips), traders will extend the order block zone to 20 pips. This mechanical rule creates a volatility-adjusted sizing system that prevents traders from using undersized order blocks that price easily breaks through. The 60% threshold represents the volatility level at which price typically breaks through without institutional respect.

The institutional principle encoded in this rule: when volatility (as measured by ATR) exceeds order block size, the zone lacks sufficient institutional order clustering to stop price. Extending to one ATR ensures traders mark zones large enough to contain institutional stop-losses. This adjustment dramatically improves order block effectiveness because traders stop marking micro-zones that lead to frequent false breakouts. The rule transforms order block marking from subjective assessment to objective, volatility-based criteria. Traders applying this rule report better success rates because their order blocks align with institutional sizing patterns rather than visual approximation.

ICT Mapping:
- 60% ATR threshold = institutional minimum order block size criteria for stop-loss clustering
- ATR extension = institutional volatility-adjusted zone sizing for institutional order grouping
- One ATR from both sides = institutional balanced zone expansion for bidirectional stop-losses
- Volatility measurement = institutional objective sizing methodology replacing visual estimation

[10:35] - [11:44] | Three Order Block Types: Continuation, Reversal, and Ranging

Now the presenter identifies three kinds of order blocks based on market structure context: continuation, reversal, and ranging. Continuation order blocks happen when price is trending upward or downward, and order blocks form aligned with the dominant trend. For example, imagine an uptrend with a series of higher highs and higher lows. Each of the demand order blocks that form along the way is an opportunity to go along with the dominant uptrend. But if a change of character appears, a supply order block automatically forms which is against the dominant uptrend. Usually the continuation order blocks have a higher chance of success because they are in line with the trend.

However, reversal order blocks have the potential to gain massive risk-to-reward ratios. The next order block type is the ranging order block. This kind of order block forms when price is in a range phase before a drastic move happens in the market. When price returns to the ranging zone, traders expect the market to reject this area and continue pushing upwards. From the visual perspective, identifying the range zone is easy—it feels like price is trapped inside a box. However, from the mechanical perspective, traders need at least four consecutive candles, each one closing back inside the range. This mechanical definition prevents traders from mistaking small consolidations for ranging order blocks.

ICT Mapping:
- Continuation order blocks = institutional aligned-trend entries with higher probability
- Reversal order blocks = institutional counter-trend with higher reward potential
- Ranging order blocks = institutional pre-breakout accumulation from price trapped pattern
- Change of character = institutional bias shift creating opposite order block formation

[11:44] - [12:55] | Combining Order Blocks with Market Structure: Top-Down Analysis Framework

All the rules and conditions discussed so far are crucial for identifying valid order blocks. However, there is one important factor that needs to be considered to increase the chance of winning trades: combining order blocks with market structure concepts. Finding an entry zone alone is not enough for a successful trade. That's why traders always apply a top-down analysis to the chart to gain a comprehensive understanding of the current market condition and future movements.

This top-down analysis consists of three major timeframes. Starting with the 4-hour chart, traders apply the concepts of market structure to find the market direction, key levels, and supply and demand areas. Following, traders zoom into 1 hour, which is the major analysis timeframe. On the 1-hour chart, traders identify the trend breaks, reversals, fair value gaps, liquidity areas, order blocks, and trading opportunities. Furthermore, traders zoom into 15 minutes to find confirmations in the lower timeframes and execute orders. This three-timeframe approach ensures that order blocks are marked within the correct market structure context, dramatically improving trading success. Traders who skip this top-down analysis often find their order blocks broken by higher timeframe momentum, a costly mistake that proper context analysis prevents.

ICT Mapping:
- Top-down analysis = institutional multi-timeframe confluence for contextual order block validity
- 4-hour market structure = institutional bias and directional context establishment
- 1-hour order blocks = institutional trading timeframe and primary entry analysis level
- 15-minute confirmations = institutional execution timeframe for entry signal activation
- Comprehensive context = institutional alignment ensuring order block respect across timeframes

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- **Learning from mistakes**: Making mistakes is inevitable in trading; learning nothing from them is the actual mistake.

- **Order blocks effectiveness**: Order blocks operate more effectively and generate profits when accompanied by specific conditions and rules.

- **Rule-based approach**: Simplified order block concept requires explaining rule-based approach toward blocks respected by market.

- **Order block definition**: Areas where buying or selling orders reside that market has rejected once and might react to again.

- **Supply/demand distinction**: Every order block is supply/demand level, but not every supply/demand area qualifies as order block.

- **Massive position creation**: Price levels create reactions showing traders opened massive buy/sell positions causing significant movements.

- **Condition accompaniment**: Supply and demand areas accompanied by certain conditions have significantly improved chance of working.

- **Inefficiency as rule 1**: Inefficiency, imbalance, and fair value gaps are highly similar concepts for valid order block identification.

- **Fair value gap formation**: Large money entering market creates imbalance between buyers/sellers forming fair value gap patterns between candles.

- **Smart money indication**: Inefficiency movements on chart show smart money entered market and affected price creating trading opportunity.

- **Remaining orders importance**: Price takes off after reaching order blocks only if remaining orders exist for accumulation and filling.

- **Fair value gap marking**: Always mark fair value gaps on chart when mapping market structure as first rule of valid order block identification.

- **Breaking market structure**: Second rule requires price movement breaking latest market structure and closing above recent high for validity.

- **Origin point significance**: Origin of price movement becomes highly important showing if demand area is ordinary or influential market zone.

- **Structural break confirmation**: Supply or demand zone considered valid order block when leading to structural break in correct direction.

- **Liquidity location**: Liquidity is where stop losses reside requiring understanding of stop-loss clustering for predatory price action.

- **Quality improvement**: Grabbing liquidity in trend direction before reaching supply/demand area improves quality of that area confirmation.

- **Three common patterns**: Three liquidity grab patterns happen every day on chart, forming each one increases trade success chance.

- **Gap magnet effect**: Fair value gaps act as magnet for price to fill, restore balance, grab liquidity before order block reaction.

- **Left-side context**: Before placing trade look at left side to see market structure conditions for avoiding unnecessary risk.

- **Equal highs/lows pattern**: Equal highs/lows contain liquidity clusters from trapped stop-losses at previous price levels.

- **Below equal lows liquidity**: In bullish scenario below equal lows contain lots of liquidity from failed short positions.

- **Above equal highs liquidity**: In bearish scenario above equal highs contain lots of liquidity from failed long positions.

- **Candlestick marking methodology**: Mark last candlestick before drastic move as order block zone regardless of candle color.

- **Buying orders residence**: Decisions made during marked candle represent area where buying/selling orders reside awaiting price return.

- **Stop placement convention**: Open position at order block zone and set stop below zone as standard risk management protocol.

- **Wick liquidity grabbing**: Sometimes wick grabs liquidity below order block candlestick requiring zone extension with adjustments.

- **Large zone trading**: Large extended order blocks require more confirmations in lower timeframes to execute trades at better price.

- **Small candlestick treatment**: Small candlestick order blocks require large stop-loss below or larger area consideration on both sides.

- **ATR indicator measurement**: Average True Range indicator measures market volatility giving average size previous 14 candles.

- **60% ATR rule**: If order block candlestick smaller than 60% of ATR extend zone to one ATR from both sides.

- **Volatility-adjusted sizing**: ATR extension creates objective volatility-based zone sizing replacing subjective visual estimation methods.

- **Continuation order blocks**: Happen when price trending and order blocks form aligned with dominant trend with higher success probability.

- **Reversal order blocks**: Form against dominant trend with potential to gain massive risk-to-reward ratio gains.

- **Ranging order blocks**: Form when price in range phase before drastic move with mechanical four-candle closing requirement.

- **Market structure combination**: Finding entry zone alone insufficient; combining order blocks with market structure concepts increases winning trades.

- **Top-down analysis framework**: Apply three-timeframe top-down analysis for comprehensive understanding of market conditions and order block validity.

- **4-hour market structure**: Establish market direction, key levels, supply and demand areas defining broader context for lower timeframe trades.

- **1-hour analysis timeframe**: Major analysis timeframe identifying trend breaks, reversals, fair value gaps, liquidity, order blocks, opportunities.

- **15-minute confirmation**: Lower timeframe finding entry confirmations and executing orders with mechanical signal activation.





================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: UNDERSTAND FOUNDATIONAL PRINCIPLE
When trading financial markets, traders make mistakes; learning nothing from those mistakes becomes the real mistake. Order blocks operate effectively and generate profits when accompanied by specific conditions and rules, not in isolation. This foundational understanding drives the need for systematic, rule-based order block identification rather than subjective visual analysis.

STEP 2: DEFINE ORDER BLOCK VERSUS SUPPLY/DEMAND
Order blocks = areas where buying/selling orders reside that market rejected once and might react to again. Supply/demand = any reaction to price level. Key distinction: every order block is supply/demand, but NOT every supply/demand qualifies as order block. This distinction requires learning to filter supply/demand zones through conditions-based criteria.

STEP 3: RECOGNIZE INEFFICIENCY AS RULE 1
Large money entering market creates imbalance between buyers/sellers forming fair value gaps and inefficiency between candles. Inefficiency indicates smart money entered market and affected price. Price returns to inefficiency areas to accumulate remaining orders creating trading opportunity. Therefore: always mark fair value gaps on chart when mapping market structure as first rule of valid order block.

STEP 4: VALIDATE BREAK OF STRUCTURE AS RULE 2
In bullish scenario: price breaks latest market structure and closes above recent high = origin of movement becomes highly important. Shows demand area creating movement is NOT ordinary level but influential area in market structure. In bearish scenario: price breaks downside showing supply area is influential. Only supply/demand zones leading to structural breaks qualify as valid order blocks meeting rule 2.

STEP 5: IDENTIFY STOP-LOSS LIQUIDITY LOCATIONS
Liquidity = where stop-losses reside. Understanding stop-loss clustering determines where price hunts. Grabbing liquidity in trend direction BEFORE reaching supply/demand area improves zone quality. This explains why price often moves past initial order blocks—it's collecting stops before respecting the block. Traders must anticipate and accept this movement.

STEP 6: RECOGNIZE THREE LIQUIDITY GRAB PATTERNS
Pattern 1: Fair value gaps below demand zones act as magnet for price to fill, grab liquidity, continue upwards. Pattern 2: Equal highs/lows contain liquidity clusters from trapped stop-losses at previous levels (below equal lows in bullish; above in bearish). Pattern 3: Additional mechanical pattern requiring chart observation. Each pattern formation before reaching order block increases trade success.

STEP 7: MARK LAST CANDLESTICK BEFORE DRASTIC MOVE
Mark last candlestick before start of drastic bullish/bearish move as order block zone. Regardless of candle color, decisions made during this candle making it important area where buying/selling orders reside. When price taps into this area again, open position and set stop below zone. This mechanical marking creates consistent zone identification.

STEP 8: APPLY ATR RULE FOR UNDERSIZED BLOCKS
If order block candlestick smaller than 60% of ATR (Average True Range), extend zone to one ATR from both sides. Example: if ATR = 20 pips and block range = 12 pips (60% of 20), extend zone to 20 pips. ATR measurement creates objective, volatility-adjusted sizing replacing subjective visual estimation, improving order block effectiveness.

STEP 9: CATEGORIZE ORDER BLOCK TYPE
Continuation: price trending, order blocks align with trend (higher success probability). Reversal: against trend (massive reward potential). Ranging: price trapped in box phase, need four consecutive candles closing inside range for mechanical confirmation. Categorization determines trading approach and risk management for each block type.

STEP 10: APPLY TOP-DOWN ANALYSIS FOR CONTEXT
Order block alone insufficient; apply three-timeframe top-down analysis. Start 4-hour: market direction, key levels, supply/demand areas. Move to 1-hour: identify trend breaks, reversals, fair value gaps, liquidity, order blocks, opportunities. Zoom 15-minute: find confirmations and execute orders. Ensure order blocks marked within correct market structure context for successful trading.
