[2:00] - [3:15] | Identifying Major Swings & Market Structure Breakouts

• Sharp bearish movement establishes low which is marked on schematic
• Peak point between consecutive lows becomes major high
• Schematic accurately drawn using major swing identification rules
• Price breaking and closing below previous structure marks new low
• Specific rules applied consistently to identify all major swings
• Peak between consecutive lows identified as next major high reference point
• Price breaking swing high upside indicates shift in market structure
• Sellers fail to hold level when buyers take control of price
• New high established when price breaks previous swing high upside
• Lowest point between consecutive highs becomes new major low
• Internal structure or minor swings exist between major swing points
• Minor swings can provide valuable trading information and opportunities
• Beginning of latest impulsive movement marks origin point of imbalance
• Supply order block located at imbalance origin for potential reversals

ICT Mapping:
- **Swing High Definition**: Highest high between two lower highs marks buy-side liquidity zone
- **Swing Low Definition**: Lowest low between two higher lows marks sell-side liquidity zone
- **Breakout Confirmation**: Close beyond previous major swing confirms structure shift
- **Order Block Origin**: First candle of impulsive move marks supply/demand accumulation
- **Imbalance Creation**: Gap between candles creates fair value gap (FVG) opportunity

(218 words) ✓

[3:15] - [4:30] | Order Blocks, Supply Zones & Price Momentum Reversals

• Extreme supply level break indicates significant loss of bearish momentum
• Price managing to break above extreme supply signals potential trend change
• Gold 4-hour chart shows latest market structure schematic
• Clear market structure movements with obvious direction and swing points
• Smart money concepts applied to find opportunities aligned with direction
• Trading long in dominant bullish direction identified from structure
• Price breaking latest swing low downside allows short entry opportunities
• Next important key demand area becomes target for extended moves
• Comparing chart with unclear direction shows continuous swing validation both sides
• Market validating major swing highs and lows to both directions
• No clear direction means staying away from market execution
• Understanding when NOT to trade equally important as identifying entry time
• Upcoming major news significantly impacts price regardless of technical
• Technical analysis must account for fundamental event risk

- **Continuous Monitoring**: Active trade management adjusts to changing market conditions

(223 words) ✓

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- **Multi-Timeframe Hierarchy**: Higher timeframes establish trend direction and key levels; lower timeframes provide entry signals and confirmation for execution

- **Three Timeframe Types**: Higher frames (weekly/daily) for bias, analysis frames (1H/4H) for structure and opportunities, entry frames (5m/15m) for precision

- **Market Structure Schematic**: Non-subjective rules identify major swings; trend direction determined by comparing recent highs/lows to previous structure

- **Major Swing Identification**: Highest high between two lower highs (swing high); lowest low between two higher lows (swing low) define key levels

- **Order Blocks**: Locations where smart money accumulated orders in previous impulsive moves; first candle of impulse marks supply/demand block origin

- **Supply Zone Breaks**: Price closing above supply area shows buyers control; enables long positions until reaching next supply zone ahead

- **Demand Zone Breaks**: Price closing below demand area shows sellers control; enables short positions until reaching next demand zone below

- **Fair Value Gap Locations**: Fibonacci retracement identifies precise FVG placement at confluence of 61.8% and 78.6% retracement levels

- **Change of Character**: When price direction changes (higher lows become lower lows, or vice versa), institutional momentum shift confirmed

- **Double Top/Bottom Patterns**: Two rejected highs (double top) or lows (double bottom) confirm supply/demand zone strength and reversal signals

- **Imbalance Creation**: Gaps between candles create fair value gaps that become future price targets for smart money execution

- **Directional Entry Rules**: Only execute trades when lower timeframe setup aligns with higher timeframe bias direction

- **Risk Management Framework**: Limit single trade risk to 2-3% of total capital; prevents severe drawdowns from derailing trading results

- **Stop Loss Placement**: Positioned below recent swing low for long trades; below highest point touched for short trades

- **Profit Target Selection**: Next unmitigated supply zone (short) or demand zone (long) provides logical profit target based on structure

- **News Event Awareness**: Monitor economic calendar; avoid trading through major fundamental events that override technical structure

- **Timeframe Cascade Approach**: Select ATF zone → confirm HTF bias → zoom LTF for precise entry → execute with calculated risk

- **Confirmation Signals**: Multiple confluence factors (double top/bottom, imbalance, momentum, structure breakout) increase entry probability

- **Backtesting Validation**: Test strategy through historical data before live trading; build confidence through proven performance metrics

- **Market Indecision Recognition**: When price validates swings both directions with no clear bias, stand aside and wait for clarity




================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: IDENTIFY TIMEFRAME HIERARCHY
Start with higher timeframes (weekly/daily) to determine overall market direction and identify key support/resistance levels that will guide all lower timeframe trading.

STEP 2: SKETCH MARKET STRUCTURE SCHEMATIC
On analysis timeframe (1H or 4H), draw schematic from lowest to highest visible price swings using objective rules to avoid subjective bias.

STEP 3: IDENTIFY MAJOR SWINGS
Using three-candle pattern rules, locate swing highs (highest point between two lower highs) and swing lows (lowest point between two higher lows).

STEP 4: RECOGNIZE SUPPLY AND DEMAND BLOCKS
Mark locations where smart money accumulated orders during previous impulsive moves; first candle of impulse marks supply/demand block origin.

STEP 5: LOCATE FAIR VALUE GAPS (FVG)
Identify gaps between candles; use Fibonacci retracement to pinpoint FVG at 61.8%-78.6% levels; note mitigated vs unmitigated status.

STEP 6: EVALUATE MARKET DIRECTION CLARITY
Assess whether price shows clear directional bias (higher highs/lows or lower highs/lows) or confused direction validating both sides.

STEP 7: CONFIRM WITH HIGHER TIMEFRAME BIAS
Verify that lower timeframe analysis aligns with higher timeframe direction; only trade lower timeframe setups matching HTF bias.

STEP 8: IDENTIFY ENTRY ZONES FROM ATF
Mark 4-hour or 1-hour supply zones (for shorts) or demand zones (for longs) where lower timeframe entries will be sought.

STEP 9: ZOOM TO LOWER TIMEFRAME FOR CONFIRMATION
Scale down to 5-minute or 15-minute charts; look for double top/bottom, imbalance creation, or change of character confirmation.

STEP 10: WAIT FOR PULLBACK TO OPTIMIZE ENTRY
Allow price to retrace from extreme move; enter on pullback rather than immediately after imbalance; improves risk-to-reward ratio.

STEP 11: PLACE PROTECTIVE STOPS
Position stop loss below swing low (long trades) or above swing high (short trades); define maximum acceptable loss per trade.

STEP 12: EXECUTE WITH RISK MANAGEMENT
Risk only 2-3% of trading capital per trade; calculate position size based on stop loss level; preserve capital for recovery from losses.

================================================================================
TRADING CHECKLISTS
================================================================================

A. TIMEFRAME & BIAS CONFIRMATION

- [ ] Opened higher timeframe (weekly/daily) chart
- [ ] Identified overall market direction (uptrend, downtrend, or indecision)
- [ ] Located key support and resistance levels on higher timeframe
- [ ] Opened analysis timeframe (1H or 4H) for detailed structure
- [ ] Sketched market structure schematic on analysis timeframe
- [ ] Confirmed lower timeframe bias matches higher timeframe direction
- [ ] Verified no conflicting fundamental news scheduled during trade
- [ ] Determined analysis timeframe clearly favors bullish or bearish
- [ ] Identified that market is NOT in indecision state

B. STRUCTURE & LIQUIDITY IDENTIFICATION

- [ ] Identified all major swing highs on analysis timeframe
- [ ] Identified all major swing lows on analysis timeframe
- [ ] Located buy-side liquidity above swing highs
- [ ] Located sell-side liquidity below swing lows
- [ ] Marked supply order blocks from impulsive moves
- [ ] Marked demand order blocks from impulsive moves
- [ ] Found fair value gaps using Fibonacci retracement (61.8%-78.6%)
- [ ] Identified mitigated vs unmitigated FVG status
- [ ] Noted multiple liquidity levels for multi-trade planning

C. ENTRY SETUP CONFIRMATION

- [ ] Zoomed to lower timeframe (15m or 5m)
- [ ] Identified double top or double bottom reversal pattern
- [ ] Confirmed imbalance created (fair value gap formed)
- [ ] Observed change of character (direction shift confirmation)
- [ ] Waited for pullback from extreme move
- [ ] Confirmed confluence of multiple entry signals present
- [ ] Selected optimal entry price vs entering immediately
- [ ] Verified risk-to-reward ratio acceptable (minimum 1:2 or better)
- [ ] Ensured entry position size calculated based on stop loss

D. EXECUTION & RISK MANAGEMENT

- [ ] Calculated position size for 2-3% risk tolerance
- [ ] Placed stop loss below swing low (long) or above swing high (short)
- [ ] Identified first profit target at next supply/demand zone
- [ ] Set up multiple exit points for partial profit taking
- [ ] Monitored trade for new order block formation or CoC signals
- [ ] Recorded trade outcome and reasoning in trading journal
- [ ] Adjusted second entry if additional order block formed
- [ ] Managed remaining position toward next major structure level
- [ ] Closed trade at stop loss or target with disciplined execution
- [ ] Reviewed trade mechanics post-execution for improvement
- [ ] Avoided revenge trading after loss or over-trading after win
- [ ] Maintained consistent risk management throughout session

• Welcome traders back to smart risk channel episode

**[10:59] - [11:41] | Stop Loss Placement Strategy for Fair Value Gap Entries**

• Fair value gap entry at highest FVG point with tight stop loss option
• Stop loss placed just below fair value gap area for tight protection
• This strategy can be effective in certain market conditions
• Stop loss becomes very tight with this fair value gap approach
• Unmitigated order block exists at extreme below fair value gap
• Price could push downward to fill unmitigated order block below
• Recommendation: keep stop loss wider by placing beneath order block
• Placing stop beneath order block maintains structural integrity
• Type of entry designed to reduce possibility of missing trade entirely
• Reduces potential missed trade frequency through wider stop loss
• Trade-off: wider stop loss reduces reward to risk ratio
• Point of this entry type: capture trade rather than miss perfectly

ICT Mapping:
- **Stop Structure**: Placing stop below OB respects institutional levels
- **Unmitigated OB Risk**: Potential downside push toward untouched OB below
- **Hit Rate vs Ratio**: Wider stops improve entry activation probability
- **Entry Philosophy**: Miss fewer trades even with reduced profit potential
- **Structural Alignment**: Stops should respect major order blocks always

(187 words) ✓

---

**[11:41] - [12:37] | Trade Outcome Comparison & Closing**

• Comparing both trade options considering outcomes
• First option: waiting for order block entry activation
• If order block entry approach: takeprofit set at high level
• Price couldn't activate buy limit order at extreme order block
• No entry triggered means no trade executed from order block approach
• Second option: entering from fair value gap instead
• Fair value gap buy limit order would have been activated
• Takeprofit would have been hit by price movement
• Trade played out successfully without pulling back to order block
• Fair value gap entry captured trade that order block entry missed
• Fair value gap entry resulted in winning trade outcome
• Order block entry resulted in missed trade outcome
• Demonstrates why fair value gap entries effective on lower timeframes
• Episode concludes with thanks for watching
• Trainer hopes video found informative and useful
• Viewers encouraged to hit subscribe button
• Notifications turned on for latest video updates
• Viewer feedback and suggestions valued by channel
• Comments section requests input on future topics
• Channel appreciation for viewer support expressed
• Looking forward to seeing viewers in next episode

ICT Mapping:
- **Entry Activation**: FVG triggered while OB missed in this scenario
- **Outcome Comparison**: FVG entry won; OB entry missed trade
- **Hit Rate Differential**: FVG showed superior execution in this example
- **Take Profit Execution**: FVG path allowed TP to be reached
- **Entry Method Selection**: Context determines which method works better
- **Educational Intent**: Video aimed to clarify entry method confusion
- **Community Building**: Engagement builds trader community around channel

- **Content Direction**: Viewer input shapes episode creation focus
- **Relationship Building**: Regular viewers become channel community members

(244 words) ✓

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- **Timeframe-Specific Entry Methods**: Higher timeframes respect order blocks more; lower timeframes respect fair value gaps more consistently

- **Order Block Basics**: Order blocks are areas where smart money accumulated previous orders; highest point on HTF, extreme points on LTF vary in respect

- **Fair Value Gap Definition**: Imbalances created between candles that often get filled; LTF FVGs show higher hit rate than extreme LTF OBs

- **Over-Refinement Problem**: Traders seeking perfection refine too much; extreme LTF OBs rarely get hit because market doesn't zigzag everywhere

- **Discount Zone Concept**: Area containing both higher and lower timeframe order blocks; represents range where institutional accumulation occurred

- **Change of Character Signal**: Price breaking and closing beyond major swing high/low confirms institutional direction shift and potential entry opportunity

- **Entry Method Trade-offs**: OB entries allow wider stops but miss more trades; FVG entries trigger more but reduce reward-to-risk ratio

- **Stop Loss Placement Logic**: HTF OB stop at lowest point; LTF FVG stop can be tight below FVG or wider below extreme OB below

- **Inefficiency Creation**: Price creates substantial gaps but doesn't fill them due to institutional momentum continuation in primary direction

- **Liquidity Void Dynamics**: Large FVGs create resistance to retracement; massive voids behind inefficiency prevent price from reaching extreme zones

- **Inducement Level Importance**: Price must take out technical levels (inducement) before reversal; validates potential reversal setup

- **Pending Order Failures**: Orders placed at obvious levels often don't execute because price continues dominant direction after creating inefficiencies

- **Risk/Reward Optimization**: Choosing entry method directly impacts whether trade gets triggered; right choice improves overall trading outcomes

- **Institutional Behavior Patterns**: Smart money uses FVG on LTF more than extreme OB; uses OB on HTF more than FVG for consistency

- **Multiple Entry Opportunities**: Missing first entry doesn't mean missing trade; second entries often available through FVG method

- **Structural Integrity**: Respect major institutional order blocks in stop placement; avoid getting caught between unmitigated blocks

- **Hit Rate Improvement**: Fair value gap entries miss fewer trades compared to extreme order block entries on lower timeframes

- **Market Reality Check**: Real markets don't behave perfectly; price won't fill every theoretical level identified in analysis

- **Scenario Elimination**: Understanding when price respects OB vs FVG prevents confusion and improves entry decision-making process

- **Trade Execution**: Enter from FVG on lower timeframes for higher probability; use OB on higher timeframes for structural alignment





================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: UNDERSTAND TIMEFRAME HIERARCHY FOR ENTRY SELECTION
Recognize that higher timeframes (1H, 4H) respect order blocks more; lower timeframes (5m, 15m) respect fair value gaps more for consistent entries.

STEP 2: IDENTIFY ORDER BLOCKS ON HIGHER TIMEFRAMES
Locate highest point of order block on 1-hour or 4-hour charts; mark as potential entry area with highest institutional accumulation likelihood.

STEP 3: IDENTIFY FAIR VALUE GAPS ON LOWER TIMEFRAMES
Find imbalances between candles on 5-minute or 15-minute charts; mark FVG areas that price likely respects before continuing directional move.

STEP 4: CONFIRM CHANGE OF CHARACTER BEFORE ENTRY
Ensure price breaks and closes beyond major swing point, confirming institutional direction; this validates entry signal strength and bias direction.

STEP 5: CREATE DISCOUNT ZONE CONTAINING BOTH HTF AND LTF BLOCKS
Map both higher and lower timeframe order blocks into single area; this zone represents where both timeframe confluences exist for highest probability.

STEP 6: PLACE ENTRY AT CORRECT PRICE LEVEL BASED ON METHOD
For order blocks: enter at highest point; for FVG: enter at highest point of gap; ensure entry respects institutional structure and timeframe hierarchy.

STEP 7: DETERMINE STOP LOSS PLACEMENT USING STRUCTURAL LEVELS
Place stops below extreme order blocks or below fair value gaps; never place stops at obvious retail levels; maintain institutional structure respect.

STEP 8: CALCULATE REWARD-TO-RISK RATIO BEFORE EXECUTION
Identify profit target at next liquidity level; calculate if reward-to-risk ratio acceptable; wider stops reduce ratio but improve hit rate on lower timeframes.

STEP 9: WATCH FOR INEFFICIENCY CREATION PREVENTING ENTRY EXECUTION
Understand price may create large gaps preventing retracement to extreme zones; institutional momentum may prevent pending order activation entirely.

STEP 10: ADAPT ENTRY METHOD IF FIRST OPPORTUNITY MISSED
If order block entry missed, shift to FVG entry on lower timeframe; FVG entries trigger more frequently when OB entries fail to activate.

STEP 11: RESPECT THAT NOT EVERY ENTRY GETS EXECUTED
Accept that some pending orders at obvious levels never activate; price can continue directional move without filling extreme levels due to momentum absorption.

STEP 12: COMBINE TIMEFRAMES FOR MAXIMUM ENTRY SUCCESS
Use HTF order blocks to establish bias direction; use LTF fair value gaps for precise entry timing; combining methods improves overall trading success rate.

================================================================================
TRADING CHECKLISTS
================================================================================

A. ENTRY METHOD IDENTIFICATION & SELECTION

- [ ] Identified current timeframe focus (higher or lower timeframe)
- [ ] Confirmed which entry method applies to timeframe (OB for HTF, FVG for LTF)
- [ ] Located order blocks on higher timeframe (if applicable)
- [ ] Located fair value gaps on lower timeframe (if applicable)
- [ ] Verified change of character confirming directional bias
- [ ] Mapped discount zone containing both HTF and LTF order blocks
- [ ] Confirmed institutional accumulation area identification
- [ ] Verified inducement level price action before major move
- [ ] Checked which entry method has higher probability for this context

B. ENTRY PREPARATION & LEVEL MARKING

- [ ] Marked highest point of order block for order block entry
- [ ] Marked highest point of fair value gap for FVG entry
- [ ] Identified next liquidity level for profit target placement
- [ ] Marked extreme order block for stop loss reference
- [ ] Verified imbalance between candles for FVG confirmation
- [ ] Checked structural support for entry level validity
- [ ] Confirmed no recent price rejection at marked entry level
- [ ] Cross-referenced entry level across multiple confirmations
- [ ] Prepared buy limit or sell limit order for execution

C. STOP LOSS & RISK MANAGEMENT SETUP

- [ ] Determined if stop loss placed below OB (wider) or below FVG (tighter)
- [ ] Verified stop loss respects extreme order block levels below
- [ ] Calculated position size based on stop loss distance
- [ ] Confirmed risk percentage per trade (typically 1-3% account)
- [ ] Verified reward-to-risk ratio acceptable (minimum 1:2 preferred)
- [ ] Placed stop loss outside obvious retail level clustering
- [ ] Confirmed stop loss maintains structural integrity
- [ ] Double-checked stop loss won't get caught between two order blocks
- [ ] Ensured stop loss distance reasonable for timeframe being traded

D. EXECUTION, MONITORING & TRADE MANAGEMENT

- [ ] Monitored price approach toward entry level
- [ ] Watched for pending order activation at marked entry point
- [ ] Confirmed entry execution and position opened successfully
- [ ] Tracked whether price creates inefficiency preventing entry
- [ ] Observed if retracement develops or price continues directional
- [ ] Monitored profit target price level approach
- [ ] Managed partial profit taking at liquidity levels
- [ ] Trailed stop loss to breakeven after partial hit
- [ ] Closed remaining position at final liquidity target
- [ ] Recorded trade outcome and entry method performance
- [ ] Updated trading journal with OB vs FVG comparison results
- [ ] Analyzed why entry triggered or didn't trigger as expected

• Video shows rules for identifying high-probability supply and demand zones respected in market
• Technique for marking zones demonstrated alongside psychology behind concepts

• Supply and demand zones require specific conditions as filters
• Understanding how to identify zones separates profitable from unprofitable traders
• Conditions determine which zones are truly important vs noise

- **Institutional Behavior**: Smart money enters market creating significant price movement patterns

- **Filter Mechanism**: Conditions ensure only high-probability zones are traded

**[1:06] - [2:51] | Supply & Demand Zone Definition & Fair Value Gap Mechanics**

• Supply and demand zones form when smart money enters market causing significant price movement
• Zone represents area where price has rapidly pushed away from with lots of orders placed
• Not every significant price reaction qualifies as key supply and demand zone
• Three major criteria required for valid zones: imbalance creation, break structural level, collect liquidity
• Areas fulfilling all criteria considered key supply and demand zones; rest are minor levels
• Imbalance, inefficiency, and fair value gaps are highly similar concepts
• Smart money creates imbalance between buyers and sellers causing price movements with gaps
• Fair value gap is three-candlestick pattern where wicks do not meet indicating inefficiency
• Efficient prices show wicks meeting in middle with no gaps or inefficiency present
• Price returning to FVG areas restores balance
• Combining FVG with S&D improves entry opportunities significantly

ICT Mapping:
- **FVG Mechanics**: Three-candle pattern with non-meeting wicks creates imbalance signals
- **Buy Side Inefficiency**: Price movement creates gaps indicating institutional momentum direction
- **Imbalance as Magnet**: Inefficiencies attract price to fill gaps and restore equilibrium
- **Supply/Demand Pairing**: FVG combined with S&D zones increases entry probability significantly
- **Institutional Ordering**: Order placement visible through gaps between candle wicks

• Example shows price moving in uptrend creating fair value gaps in specific area
• Fair value gaps indicate buyside imbalance with sellside inefficiency present
• Demand zone identified below imbalance indicating zone contributed to gap creation
• Two demand zones compared: one with imbalance, one without imbalance attached
• Demand zone with no imbalance shows reduced probability for deep retracement scenario
• Demand zone that created initial imbalance acts as greater magnet for price
• Inefficiency acts as magnet attracting price to fill gaps and restore balance
• Trading strategy targets demand or supply zones that created imbalance patterns
• Zones creating imbalance show greater probability reversing price versus efficient zones
• Understanding difference between imbalance vs non-imbalance zones critical for setup selection
• Primary zones rank higher than secondary zones for entry opportunities

ICT Mapping:
- **Dual-Zone Recognition**: Identifying zones with and without imbalances improves selection
- **Magnetic Attraction**: Inefficiency areas pull price toward reversal levels powerfully
- **Probability Weighting**: Zones creating imbalance rank higher than secondary zones
- **Retracement Logic**: Deeper retracements target original imbalance-creating zones first
- **Setup Hierarchy**: Primary vs secondary zones determine position entry opportunities

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- **Three-Criteria Zone Validation**: Valid supply/demand zones require imbalance creation, structural break, AND liquidity collection (third as confirmation)

- **Fair Value Gap Definition**: Three-candlestick pattern with non-meeting wicks indicates inefficiency and institutional price movement patterns

- **Imbalance as Magnet**: Inefficiencies created during smart money entry act as powerful magnets attracting price back to fill gaps and restore balance

- **Multiple Zone Analysis**: Demand zones with imbalance show greater reversal probability than secondary zones without attached imbalance patterns

- **Change of Character**: Breaking and closing through major structure levels confirms institutional direction shift and market regime change

- **Liquidity Sweep Mechanics**: Valid sweep shows wick breakthrough at liquidity level with immediate close back into range or next candle inside

- **Supply Chain Concept**: Bearish trends create repeated supply zone respects establishing predictable supply chain patterns for traders

- **Demand Candle Timing**: Last recent candle before inefficiency represents zone because decisions made during that specific candle period

- **Risk-Reward Optimization**: Larger zones catch price but reduce profit potential; smaller zones increase ratio but risk missed entries

- **Wick Liquidity Consideration**: Wicks penetrating below candles sweep stops affecting zone boundaries and entry decision-making processes

- **Lower Timeframe Confirmation**: HTF zone establishment combined with LTF confirmation provides high-probability entry execution at better prices

- **Trend-Adapted Pullbacks**: Strong trends show small pullbacks not reaching marked zones causing missed trades; deeper retracements penetrate zones

- **Stop-Loss Placement**: Stops positioned below swing lows maintain structural integrity preventing early exits from valid reversal zones

- **Backtesting Requirement**: Historical data verification builds trader confidence and prepares for potential risks before real money implementation

- **Institutional Entry Visualization**: Imbalance patterns show smart money entry points through gap observation between candle wicks clearly

- **Rejection Pattern Recognition**: Price pullback to zone getting rejected indicates which side (supply or demand) controls market currently

- **Liquidity Grab Confirmation**: Grab patterns inside zones confirm short-term structure shifts preceding next directional movement strongly

- **Order Flow Psychology**: Retail stop-losses become smart money entry liquidity; buying pressure absorbs seller orders systematically

- **Chart Marking Methodology**: Consistent candle and area identification creates repeatable zone-marking process applicable across all market conditions

- **Reversal Signal Integration**: Combining CoC concept with liquidity sweep patterns provides perfect insight into future price movements



================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: IDENTIFY IMBALANCE PATTERN
Look for price movement creating fair value gaps between candle wicks; three-candle pattern where wicks don't meet shows inefficiency/imbalance created.

STEP 2: CONFIRM MARKET STRUCTURE BREAK
Verify price breaks previous support or resistance level through structural analysis; consecutive moves confirming higher highs or lower lows establish direction.

STEP 3: MARK CANDLE CREATING IMBALANCE
Identify specific candle that created the imbalance/gap; this candle represents the supply or demand zone since decisions made during this period.

STEP 4: ASSESS LIQUIDITY SWEEP CONFIRMATION
Observe if price swept liquidity below/above zone; wick breakthrough followed by immediate close back inside range signals reversal probability rising.

STEP 5: DETERMINE ZONE BOUNDARIES
Decide zone size based on three factors: risk-to-reward ratio needed, stop-loss placement below structural level, and retracement depth expected.

STEP 6: APPLY TIMEFRAME HIERARCHY
Use higher timeframe zones to establish directional bias; lower timeframe zones provide precise entry points when price approaches HTF zone.

STEP 7: OBSERVE CHANGE OF CHARACTER
Watch price breaking and closing through supply zone upside or demand zone downside; CoC confirms institutional direction shift validity.

STEP 8: IDENTIFY SUPPLY CHAIN PATTERNS
In bearish trends watch for repeated supply zone respects creating predictable patterns; same methodology identifies zones sequentially throughout trend.

STEP 9: EVALUATE PULLBACK BEHAVIOR
Assess whether market pullbacks reach zones (deep retracement) or skip zones (small pullbacks in strong trends) affecting zone selection strategy.

STEP 10: CONSIDER WICK ZONE INCLUSION
Decide whether to add wick liquidity zones to main zone boundaries based on risk-reward ratio; larger zones sacrifice ratio for higher probability.

STEP 11: IMPLEMENT LOWER TIMEFRAME CONFIRMATION
When price approaches HTF zone zoom into lower timeframes; wait for specific entry confirmation patterns before executing trade at better price.

STEP 12: BACKTEST STRATEGY PERFORMANCE
Apply zone identification rules to historical data; verify strategy profitability, build trader confidence, and prepare for potential risks before real money trading.

# Episode 70: Strong and Weak Structural Points - Market Structure Foundation




**[0:00] - [0:54] | Introduction to Structural Point Identification**

• Identifying strong and weak structural points is crucial for chart analysis
• Strong/weak points help traders gain additional information about price movement
• Insights into upcoming and future price moves determined through structural analysis
• Strong and weak points show price's general direction for traders
• Identifies whether market trending upward, downward, or sideways
• These points may indicate potential reversals in market structure
• Used to decide about entering or exiting trades
• Sets stop-loss orders based on structural confirmation
• Identifies potential price targets for position management
• Foundational concept for smart money trading methodology

ICT Mapping:
- **MSS (Market Structure Shift)**: Strong/weak points define market regime changes
- **Structural Breaks**: Price breaking structure creates opposite-side zones
- **Bias Determination**: Structure determines uptrend, downtrend, or ranging bias
- **Risk Management**: Structural points set logical stop-loss placements
- **Entry/Exit Logic**: Structure breaks confirm entry and exit timing

(95 words) ✓

---

**[0:54] - [1:03] | Music/Transition**

(Music segment - no content)

---

**[1:03] - [2:51] | Bullish Structure Recognition and Strong/Weak Points**

• Recognizing strong and weak structural points essential for market structure mapping
• Identifying supply and demand levels depends on structural recognition
• Anticipating price reversals requires understanding structural changes
• Managing risk depends on identifying structural support and resistance
• Determining entry and exit points based on structural breaks
• Strong low created when price breaks structure to upside in bullish scenario
• In uptrend, price creates multiple breaks of structures to upside
• Break of structure formation also creates strong low point simultaneously
• Weak high created when price cannot break below most recent strong low
• After break of structure and strong low formation, price retraces downward
• Price couldn't break below strong low point, creating weak structural point
• Weak high broken means new strong low will be created in market
• Strong low holds as support; price bounces upward after retracement
• High represents weak structural point when price cannot break below strong low
• Pullback phase shows price respecting most recent strong structural level

ICT Mapping:
- **BOS (Break of Structure)**: Upside breaks create strong lows in bullish market
- **Support/Resistance**: Strong low acts as magnet for price returning
- **Weak Points**: Inability to break below strong low creates weak high
- **Directional Bias**: Series of higher highs/lows confirms bullish continuation
- **Reversal Warning**: Weak high breaking signals potential bias change

(240 words) ✓

---

**[2:51] - [3:53] | Bearish Structure Recognition and Structural Point Dynamics**

• Bearish structure operates inverse to bullish scenario dynamics
• Strong high created when price breaks structure to downside
• Downtrend shows price creating series of lower lows and lower highs
• Strong high at extreme represents primary structural resistance level
• Price couldn't break upside past strong high, confirming bearish control
• Weak low created after retracement when price fails upside penetration
• Weak low breaking means new strong high will be created
• Price broke weak low to downside, creating strong high point
• Continues pushing lower after creating pullback pattern
• Cannot break above most recent strong high point in pullback
• Weak low created right after failed upside attempt in bearish trend
• Another break of structure to downside creates new strong high
• Strong high appears as price pushes downside in continuation move
• Series of lower lows and lower highs confirms bearish trend continuation
• Structural recognition shows alternating strong/weak point creation pattern

ICT Mapping:
- **Bearish BOS**: Downside breaks create strong highs in downtrends
- **Rejection Pattern**: Price rejection at strong high confirms bearish momentum
- **Weak Lows**: Failed upside creates weak low points for breakout targets
- **Lower Highs/Lows**: Series confirms downtrend structural validity
- **Reversal Confirmation**: Breaking weak low to downside creates new strong high

(201 words) ✓

• Created series of higher highs and higher lows

• Analysis based on identification of primary strong low extreme
• Price pushed upside with rally movement showing bullish momentum
• Price created pullback after rally upward movement
• Couldn't break last strong low during pullback phase
• High from pullback considered weak structural high point
• Price pushed upside and attempted breaking recent weak high level
• Unsuccessful upside attempt at weak high indicates internal weakness
• Internal low represents weak structural point at pullback
• Subsequent upside move breaks above recent weak high successfully
• Break above weak high creates strong low right at that level
• When weak high broken, new strong low created automatically
• Multiple examples show consistent structural pattern application

ICT Mapping:

- **Weak High Breaks**: Each break above weak high creates new strong low
- **Pattern Recognition**: Multiple breaks show consistent structural behavior
- **Trend Confirmation**: Higher highs/lows maintain bullish bias continuation

**[4:08] - [5:37] | Continued Bullish Structure and Sideways Phase Recognition**

• Continue pattern shows price couldn't push below last strong low
• Tiny pullback formed before price pushed upside again
• High considered weak high due to failed downside penetration
• Looking higher, price created another break of structure upside
• Closing above recent weak high creates strong low at formation
• Bullish break of structure (BOS) confirmed at weak high break point
• Price pushed upside entering temporary pausing phase
• High created during sideways phase cannot be considered structural point
• Price in sideways phase does not break any structural point
• Strong low or weak high must be broken to create structural point
• Sideways phase shows consolidation before next directional move
• Structural points only created when price breaks previous structure
• High in ranging market lacks structural confirmation criteria
• Temporary pause before price resumes directional movement
• Structural analysis suspended during sideways consolidation phases

ICT Mapping:
- **Sideways Phase**: Ranging market suspends strong/weak point creation
- **Structural Breakout**: Break from range creates new strong low
- **BOS Confirmation**: Closing above weak high triggers strong low formation
- **Consolidation Logic**: Temporary pause precedes next structural move
- **Point Validity**: Only breaks create structural points, not range highs

---

**[5:37] - [6:18] | Breaking Strong Structural Points and Opposite Side Zones**

• When price breaks strong structural points, market creates opposite side zones
• Bullish scenario shows price created most recent high
• Price pushed downside breaking last strong low to downside
• High had enough power breaking most recent strong low
• Price going through last strong low creates opposite side zone (supply)
• Strong low being broken by price creates strong high automatically
• Same concepts apply to bearish scenario structure analysis
• If price breaks most recent strong high, creates strong low automatically
• Breaking strong high creates new demand area for traders
• Price always creates opposite side zones when breaking strong points
• Supply zone location at extreme after strong low broken
• Demand zone creation happens when strong high broken downside
• Opposite zone placement occurs at breakout point extreme level
• Traders use opposite zones for next directional target setup
• Strong point breaks signal major institutional momentum shifts

ICT Mapping:
- **Opposite Zones**: Breaking strong points creates reverse-side supply/demand
- **Supply Creation**: Breaking strong low creates supply zone at extreme
- **Demand Creation**: Breaking strong high creates demand zone at extreme
- **Momentum Signal**: Strong point breaks show major directional move incoming
- **Zone Targeting**: Opposite zones become next reversal/rebound targets

(221 words) ✓

• Only strong structural point on chart after strong high creation
• Price retraced down but couldn't break below strong high extreme
• This high considered weak structural high in analysis
• Price continued primary direction attempting break above weak high
• Unsuccessful break indicated internal low as weak structural point
• Price pushed downside breaking below last weak low point
• Creating weak high as result of failed downside penetration attempt
• Two possible scenarios exist when price at weak high/strong low range
• First scenario: price goes through extreme weak high creates strong low
• Low breaking through extreme weak high represents strong structural low
• Second scenario: price breaks through last strong low point
• In second scenario, weak high becomes strong structural high
• Another structure example showing multiple strong and weak point identification

ICT Mapping:
- **Scenario Planning**: Two paths from weak high/strong low formation
- **Extreme Breaks**: Breaking through extremes confirms structural shift
- **Point Transformation**: Weak points become strong when structure breaks
- **Range Dynamics**: Price locked in range between weak/strong extremes
- **Next Move Probability**: Both scenarios have preparation rules

• This high represents strong structural resistance point
• Next low is weak because price couldn't break last strong high upside
• Another weak point where price couldn't break any structure downside
• This low also weak because couldn't break last strong high upside
• Strong high formed by breaking out two successive structures downside
• Really strong structural high created by double structure break downside
• Next weak low created because it couldn't break last strong high
• Finally strong high formed by breaking last weak low downside
• Bearish break of structure (BOS) at this strong high point
• Multiple examples show repeated weak and strong point creation pattern
• Consolidation patterns show price locked between strong and weak extremes
• Each structure break creates opposite structural point automatically

- **Real Application**: Live chart validates structural point theory completely

(446 words) ✓

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- **Structural Point Definition**: Strong points created by breaking structure; weak points created by failed penetration attempts

- **Bullish Strong Low**: Price breaking structure to upside in bullish trend creates strong low as support

- **Bullish Weak High**: Price unable to break below strong low creates weak high at pullback resistance

- **Bearish Strong High**: Price breaking structure to downside in bearish trend creates strong high as resistance

- **Bearish Weak Low**: Price unable to break above strong high creates weak low at pullback support

- **Opposite Zone Creation**: Breaking strong low creates supply zone; breaking strong high creates demand zone

- **Multiple Breaks Confirm**: Series of higher highs/lows (uptrend) or lower lows/highs (downtrend) confirms structure

- **Weak Point Transformation**: Weak high becomes strong low when price breaks above; weak low becomes strong high when price breaks below

- **Sideways Phase Suspension**: Ranging market does not create new structural points until breaking structure

- **Pullback Dynamics**: Pullback unable to break recent strong point creates opposite weak point

- **Double Structure Breaks**: Breaking two successive structures creates very strong structural point

- **Retracement Limits**: Price cannot penetrate beyond strong point during minor retracements

- **Institutional Control**: Breaking strong point signals which side (bulls or bears) has institutional momentum

- **Entry Confirmation**: Price breaking weak point confirms structural bias and entry timing

- **Exit Planning**: Strong points ahead mark logical reversal targets and exit levels

- **Risk Management**: Stop-loss placement below (uptrend) or above (downtrend) weak point after strong point break

- **Trend Continuation**: Series of strong low creations (uptrend) or strong high creations (downtrend) confirms trend

- **Reversal Warning**: Inability to create new strong points in direction signals potential reversal coming

- **Chart Pattern Recognition**: Consolidation shows price locked between weak high and strong low extremes

- **Real Chart Application**: Live EUR/USD example demonstrates consistent pattern replication across actual price data




================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: IDENTIFY MARKET TREND DIRECTION
Observe price action determining if market trending upward (higher highs/lows), downward (lower lows/highs), or sideways (ranging).

STEP 2: LOCATE EXTREME PRICE LEVELS
Find lowest point in uptrend or highest point in downtrend to establish initial strong structural point baseline.

STEP 3: MARK BREAK OF STRUCTURE OCCURRENCE
When price breaks above previous extreme (uptrend) or below previous extreme (downtrend), mark strong point creation.

STEP 4: IDENTIFY PULLBACK FORMATION
Observe pullback move back toward recently broken structure after strong point creation.

STEP 5: DETERMINE WEAK POINT CREATION
Measure if pullback cannot penetrate recent strong point; creates weak structural point at pullback extreme.

STEP 6: CONFIRM NEXT BREAKOUT DIRECTION
Watch if price breaks above weak point (continues bullish) or below weak point (continues bearish).

STEP 7: RECOGNIZE OPPOSITE ZONE CREATION
When price breaks strong point in new direction, opposite side zone (supply/demand) forms at breakout extreme.

STEP 8: TRACK STRUCTURAL POINT SEQUENCE
Follow pattern of alternating strong/weak point creation through multiple break of structure occurrences.

STEP 9: ASSESS STRONG POINT STRENGTH
Evaluate if strong point created from single break or multiple successive breaks (double breaks = very strong).

STEP 10: DETECT SIDEWAYS PHASE SUSPENSION
Note that ranging/consolidating markets do not create new structural points until breaking structure.

STEP 11: PLAN ENTRY FROM WEAK POINT BREAK
When weak point is broken, structural bias confirmed; enter position when weak point breaks.

STEP 12: SET EXITS AT NEXT STRONG POINT
Place profit targets and reversals at next strong structural point ahead in direction of breakout.

================================================================================
TRADING CHECKLISTS
================================================================================

A. STRUCTURAL POINT IDENTIFICATION & MARKING

- [ ] Confirmed market trend direction (uptrend/downtrend/sideways)
- [ ] Located extreme price level as baseline strong point
- [ ] Identified break of structure occurrence above/below extreme
- [ ] Marked break of structure candle/bar location precisely
- [ ] Confirmed strong point creation at break location
- [ ] Observed pullback formation after strong point
- [ ] Measured pullback extent relative to strong point
- [ ] Identified weak point creation at pullback extreme
- [ ] Verified weak point cannot penetrate strong point
- [ ] Noted strong point strength (single vs double break)

B. STRUCTURAL PATTERN RECOGNITION & CONFIRMATION

- [ ] Observed price behavior at strong point (rejection/bounce)
- [ ] Confirmed pullback cannot break below strong low (uptrend)
- [ ] Confirmed pullback cannot break above strong high (downtrend)
- [ ] Identified weak high/low formation in pullback phase
- [ ] Noted price action testing weak point multiple times
- [ ] Confirmed weak point eventually broken in direction
- [ ] Tracked alternating strong/weak point creation pattern
- [ ] Verified sideways phase suspension of structural creation
- [ ] Assessed consolidation range between weak/strong extremes
- [ ] Detected when new structural move initiating from consolidation

C. OPPOSITE ZONE PLANNING & SETUP PREPARATION

- [ ] Determined which strong point is being broken
- [ ] Calculated opposite zone location at breakout extreme
- [ ] Identified supply zone creation (breaking strong low)
- [ ] Identified demand zone creation (breaking strong high)
- [ ] Located zone at precise breakout price extreme
- [ ] Confirmed zone will attract price on next reversal
- [ ] Planned next reversal target using opposite zone
- [ ] Noted opposite zone timing for future pullback entry
- [ ] Assessed multiple opposite zones for stacked opportunities
- [ ] Prepared for potential range bound at opposite zone

D. EXECUTION, MANAGEMENT & PERFORMANCE TRACKING

- [ ] Executed entry upon weak point break confirmation
- [ ] Confirmed structural bias match before entry
- [ ] Set stop-loss below next strong point (opposite direction)
- [ ] Placed first target at next strong point (same direction)
- [ ] Monitored price action at strong points during trade
- [ ] Tracked whether strong points hold support/resistance
- [ ] Adjusted stop loss when price breaks new strong point
- [ ] Managed partial profits at opposite zone target
- [ ] Journaled structural point behavior each trade
- [ ] Reviewed how strong/weak points predicted price action

**[0:00] - [1:13] | Introduction to Crypto Bull Run and Video Overview**

• Witnessing one of biggest crypto bull runs with Bitcoin exceeding all-time high

• Investing in crypto isn't always easy; some projects end up worthless
• Investors can lose all their money in failed crypto projects
• Crypto market has both opportunities and significant risks
• Making profit depends on finding right coins to invest in

**[1:25] - [2:49] | Bitcoin Halving Explanation and Historical Price Impact**

• Bitcoin surpassed all-time high just month before Bitcoin halving
• Bitcoin halving occurs every 4 years when block reward for miners is halved
• Halving event called "Bitcoin halving" reduces miner rewards by 50%
• Process will continue until all 21 million Bitcoins are issued
• Question posed: will halving impact Bitcoin price and cause it to rise
• Historical analysis examines previous halving events: 2012, July 2016, May 2020
• Short-term (2-3 weeks after halving): not much usually happens, only volatility
• Longer term (3-6 months after halving): significant price movements observed
• 2012 halving: major rally occurred, Bitcoin price increased 10 times within 6 months by April
• 2016 halving: similar pattern emerged with one-year-long major bull market
• 2016 halving drove Bitcoin price from $600 to $18,000 over one year
• 2020 halving: six-month ranging market before Bitcoin started taking off
• Conclusion: market direction tends to be bullish, cycle eventually takes off
• Exact timing of rally beginning is very hard to predict
• May witness sideways market even couple months after halving event

ICT Mapping:
- **Accumulation Phase**: Halving creates consolidation before markup similar to ICT consolidation
- **Market Cycles**: 4-year halving cycle represents macro-level market structure shifts
- **Liquidity Events**: Halving acts as major liquidity event attracting institutional flows
- **Ranging Markets**: Post-halving consolidation parallels ICT range expansion concepts
- **Bullish Bias Confirmation**: Historical rallies confirm long-term bullish bias post-halving

(218 words) ✓

**[2:49] - [3:28] | Bitcoin Price Rise Impact on Overall Cryptocurrency Market**

• Bitcoin price rise creates positive sentiment in overall cryptocurrency market
• Increased investor confidence results from Bitcoin price increases
• Investment flows into other cryptocurrencies when Bitcoin rises
• Can result in general uptrend across many cryptocurrencies
• However, doesn't necessarily guarantee all other coins will rise simultaneously
• Market correlation between Bitcoin and altcoins is strong but not absolute
• Positive Bitcoin momentum attracts capital to broader crypto ecosystem
• Sentiment-driven rally can lift multiple crypto assets together
• Individual coin fundamentals still matter despite Bitcoin correlation
• Timing of altcoin rallies may lag behind Bitcoin's initial move

ICT Mapping:
- **Market Correlation**: Bitcoin acts as index for crypto similar to how DXY affects forex
- **Liquidity Flow**: Bitcoin rally directs institutional money into broader crypto markets
- **Sentiment Shift**: Positive Bitcoin price action shifts market bias from bearish to bullish
- **Lagging Response**: Altcoins respond with delay similar to correlated pairs in forex
- **Independent Structure**: Each coin maintains own market structure despite correlation

**[3:28] - [4:30] | Smaller Cap Coins Definition and Market Capitalization Concept**

• Investors often prefer investing in smaller cap coins instead of Bitcoin
• Several reasons drive preference for smaller cap coins over Bitcoin
• Smaller cap coins have potential for significant price appreciation over short period
• Can lead to substantial returns for investors seeking growth
• Potential for large gains attracts investors seeking high-risk high-reward opportunities
• Smaller cap coin term refers to cryptocurrency coins with relatively smaller market capitalization
• Market cap compared to top coins determines if coin is "smaller cap"
• Crypto market cap refers to market capitalization of cryptocurrency
• Market cap is total value of certain cryptocurrency in circulation
• Calculated by multiplying total number of coins in circulation by current market price
• Example: Bitcoin market cap was $357 billion as of September 22nd, 2022
• Multiplying all Bitcoins in circulation by current price gives total market value
• Market cap calculation provides objective measure of cryptocurrency size
• Smaller market cap means more room for price appreciation percentage-wise
• Larger market cap means more stability but less explosive growth potential

ICT Mapping:
- **Position Sizing**: Market cap determines position size similar to ICT risk management
- **Volatility Profile**: Smaller caps = higher volatility like lower liquidity pairs
- **Growth Potential**: Small caps represent "discount" pricing for future premium
- **Risk Assessment**: Market cap size indicates risk level similar to lot size decisions
- **Capital Efficiency**: Smaller caps allow larger percentage gains with less capital

(235 words) ✓

---

**[4:30] - [6:42] | Altcoins vs Meme Coins and Risk-Reward Spectrum**

• Two terms come to mind when discussing smaller cap coins: altcoins and meme coins
• Altcoin is general term describing any cryptocurrency serving as alternative to Bitcoin
• Altcoins cover wide range of projects with varying technology, uses, market values
• Examples include Ethereum, Ripple, Litecoin, and many others
• Altcoins aim to tackle specific Bitcoin limitations: scalability, privacy, functionality
• May offer unique features or applications not available in Bitcoin
• Meme coin is type of cryptocurrency primarily influenced by internet memes
• Driven by social media trends and community involvement rather than fundamentals
• Not based on fundamental technological or financial principles
• Meme coins often have light-hearted or satirical nature
• May be created as joke or parody of traditional cryptocurrencies
• Value and popularity driven by viral internet trends, social media influencers, online communities
• Not driven by underlying technology or utility like traditional coins
• Examples: Dogecoin, Shiba Inu, Pepe, other meme-inspired cryptocurrencies
• Summary: altcoins = diverse features/purposes; meme coins = meme/culture driven
• Trading meme coins carries exceptionally high level of risk
• Tend to either skyrocket by thousands of times or plummet to zero
• Very little middle ground with meme coin price action
• Smaller market cap cryptos inherently high risk but higher reward potential
• Large cap cryptos lower risk but may not yield significant returns
• Midcaps fall somewhere in between risk-reward spectrum
• Meme coins typically fall at extreme end of small market caps spectrum
• Micromarket caps pose extremely high risk but potentially high rewards
• Prudent to maintain balanced crypto portfolio: large caps, midcaps, small caps
• Diversification across market cap sizes manages overall portfolio risk

ICT Mapping:
- **Risk Spectrum**: Market cap size determines risk similar to ICT stop-loss distance
- **Volatility Management**: Meme coins = extreme volatility requiring tight risk controls
- **Portfolio Balance**: Diversification across caps like diversifying across currency pairs
- **Reward-to-Risk**: Smaller caps offer better R:R similar to high-probability ICT setups
- **Market Maturity**: Large caps = established trends; small caps = emerging opportunities

(320 words) ✓

**[6:42] - [7:37] | Meme Coin Chart Patterns and Revival Catalyst Discussion**

• Examining chart of nearly every meme coin reveals similar pattern
• Usually begins with big jump in value because people speculating
• Followed by crash after initial speculation phase
• Few recovery waves attempt to regain lost ground
• Then period of ranging/consolidation after recovery attempts
• Pattern occurs because many bots invest in meme coins automatically
• Bots find coins on decentralized exchange aggregators like Dex Tools
• Bots hoping for quick gains which rarely materialize
• Once meme coins flatline, two possibilities exist
• Either coins fade into obscurity and die completely
• Or coins experience recovery and second life
• Usually takes significant catalyst to awaken meme coin from slumber
• Unfortunately for most meme coins, catalyst never materializes
• In theory, impossible to predict if and when revival catalyst will occur
• However in practice, several factors to consider
• Factors could increase likelihood of revival event occurring
• These factors will be covered in next videos (future content)

ICT Mapping:
- **Accumulation/Distribution**: Initial pump = distribution; flatline = accumulation phase
- **Liquidity Grabs**: Bot-driven spikes represent liquidity hunts before crashes
- **Market Maker Behavior**: Pump-and-dump patterns show market maker manipulation
- **Consolidation Ranges**: Flatline periods = ranging markets waiting for catalyst
- **Catalyst Events**: Revival catalysts similar to news events breaking consolidation

**[9:43] - [11:07] | Market Direction Identification and Structure Schematic Method**

• First step of trading plan: identify market direction
• Can use any timeframe to start with depending on trade duration goal
• Seeking short-term or long-term trade determines starting timeframe
• However, recommend using higher timeframes: 4-hour and 1-hour
• Higher timeframes better for determining current market direction
• Lower timeframes contain lot of noise making analysis frustrating
• Could be frustrating to identify market sentiment on lower timeframes
• Starting analysis on 1-hour chart as base timeframe
• First step: draw market structure schematic
• Schematic helps understand market direction and structure
• Outlined from lowest point to highest points of visible swings
• Example shows how to map swings of market structure
• Can draw some internal structures onto chart as well
• Main goal of schematic: see recent movements of bulls and bears
• Line chart format gives clearer idea of who is in control
• Try to make schematic as simple as possible for clarity
• In bullish market, want price to respect demand areas
• Continue making higher highs and higher lows in uptrend
• If price breaks and closes below demand area: buyers losing control
• If continues making one, two, three moves downside: potential new bearish trend
• If breaks high to upside: buyers still in control, look for long opportunities
• Same concept applied to bearish scenario in reverse

ICT Mapping:
- **Market Structure**: Schematic mapping = ICT's structure breaks and BOS identification
- **Higher Timeframe Bias**: 4H/1H analysis mirrors ICT's HTF directional bias
- **Swing Mapping**: Identifying swings = ICT's CHoCH and MSS analysis
- **Demand/Supply Zones**: Respect of zones = ICT's PD array recognition
- **Control Identification**: Bulls vs bears = ICT's institutional orderflow direction

(274 words) ✓

---

**[11:07] - [12:09] | Higher Timeframe Key Levels and Top-Down Analysis**

• After identifying direction, zoom out to higher timeframes
• Find higher timeframe key levels for broader context
• Main reason: see how much space exists before next important level
• Space assessment helps gauge trade potential and room to run
• Determine where to set long-term targets using HTF levels
• For this top-down analysis, use three timeframes: weekly, daily, 4-hour
• When identifying key levels, focus on most important criteria
• First criterion: more touches are better for level validity
• More touches indicate more people paying attention to that area
• When price reaches level, traders more likely to react at tested zones
• Second criterion: long wicks indicate immediate price rejection
• Long wicks increase likelihood of rejection again at same level
• Third criterion: drastic move away with imbalance suggests strong participation
• Significant amount of money taken action in that area
• Imbalance shows institutional involvement and conviction
• Multiple criteria confirmation strengthens key level identification
• Key levels act as magnets and reversal zones for price action
• Proper level identification critical for target setting and risk management

ICT Mapping:
- **Higher Timeframe Levels**: HTF keys = ICT's weekly/monthly PD arrays and liquidity zones
- **Top-Down Analysis**: 3-timeframe approach mirrors ICT's multi-TF methodology
- **Level Touches**: Multiple tests = strong institutional reference points
- **Rejection Wicks**: Immediate rejection = ICT's mitigation and displacement concept
- **Imbalance**: FVG creation showing one-sided institutional orderflow

**[12:57] - [14:01] | Fibonacci Retracement Trading Setup and Live Chart Application**

• Trading setup recommended: based on simple retracement and Fibonacci levels
• Essentially when trading crypto: want to buy low and sell high
• Once identified latest impulsive movement aligned with direction
• Apply Fibonacci retracement tool from start of move to end
• Anywhere between 61.8% and 78.6% levels = excellent entry area
• Excellent area to place long position in bullish scenario
• Same principle applies to bearish scenario in reverse
• Stop loss placed below swing low to protect position
• Can target first level in front of price as take-profit
• Now applying all concepts step by step on live chart
• Example: SOL 1-hour timeframe analysis
• Market recently shifted to bullish by breaking above supply zones
• Latest market schematic clearly making higher highs and higher lows
• Zoom out to higher timeframe to see bigger picture
• Daily timeframe: identify two key levels near current price
• Zoom into 4-hour timeframe for refinement
• Adjust daily levels based on 4-hour candles
• Draw 4-hour levels if visible on that timeframe
• Level acted as both support and resistance multiple times
• 4-hour price action shows price recently rejected daily level
• Still have room before reaching next key level above
• Return to 1-hour chart to execute trade
• Latest impulsive move started at specific point and extended upward
• Apply Fibonacci retracement tool marking 61.8% to 78.6% area
• This is optimal demand zone for trade entry
• Can set buy position in middle of this range
• Put stop below swing low, target next level in front of price
• Alternatively, wait for pullback and zoom to lower timeframes
• Find more confirmation such as double bottom inside this range

ICT Mapping:
- **Optimal Entry Zone**: 61.8%-78.6% Fib = ICT's optimal trade entry (OTE) zone
- **Impulsive Move**: Displacement leg = ICT's displacement and expansion concept
- **Swing Low Protection**: Stop below swing = protecting against liquidity grab
- **Multi-TF Confirmation**: Lower TF confirmation = ICT's refined entry timing
- **Demand Zone**: Fib retracement zone = ICT's discount array for longs

================================================================================
SUMMARY: KEY BULLETS
================================================================================

- **Bitcoin Bull Run**: Bitcoin exceeded all-time high one month before halving event creating bullish sentiment

- **Halving Event Impact**: Occurs every 4 years; historically leads to major price rallies 3-6 months post-event

- **Market Timing Uncertainty**: Exact timing of post-halving rally very hard to predict; may see sideways consolidation first

- **Bitcoin Market Influence**: Bitcoin price rise creates positive sentiment leading to increased investment flows into altcoins

- **Smaller Cap Opportunity**: Smaller cap coins offer potential for significant price appreciation over short periods

- **Market Capitalization**: Calculated by multiplying total coins in circulation by current market price

- **Altcoins Definition**: Any cryptocurrency serving as alternative to Bitcoin with diverse features and purposes

- **Meme Coins Characteristics**: Driven by internet memes, social media trends, and community involvement rather than fundamentals

- **High Risk-Reward**: Meme coins either skyrocket by thousands of times or plummet to zero with little middle ground

- **Portfolio Balance**: Prudent to maintain balanced portfolio comprising large caps, midcaps, and small caps

- **Meme Coin Patterns**: Typical pattern shows initial pump, crash, recovery waves, then extended ranging period

- **Revival Catalyst**: Most meme coins never experience catalyst needed to awaken from post-crash slumber

- **Trading Platform**: Bybit ranks as second largest cryptocurrency exchange globally after Binance

- **Strategy Definition**: Must have well-defined crypto trading and risk management strategy before trading

- **Technical Analysis Universality**: Technical analysis strategies that work in forex also work in crypto markets

- **Multi-Timeframe Approach**: Strategy relies on market direction, higher timeframe key levels, and optimal retracement levels

- **Higher Timeframe Preference**: Recommend using 4-hour and 1-hour timeframes to determine current market direction

- **Structure Schematic**: Draw from lowest to highest points of visible swings to understand market control

- **Key Level Criteria**: More touches, long rejection wicks, and drastic moves with imbalance indicate strong levels

- **Fibonacci Entry Zone**: 61.8% to 78.6% retracement levels represent excellent entry areas for positions

- **Backtesting Importance**: Must conduct own backtesting before placing trades with real money to build confidence

- **Stop Loss Placement**: Always place stop loss below swing low (longs) or above swing high (shorts) for protection

- **Risk Management Necessity**: Crypto market's massive profit potential comes with significant risks requiring solid management plan




================================================================================
PLAIN-LANGUAGE LOGIC STEPS
================================================================================

STEP 1: UNDERSTAND BITCOIN HALVING CYCLE
Recognize that Bitcoin halving occurs every 4 years, historically leading to major price rallies 3-6 months post-event, though exact timing unpredictable.

STEP 2: ASSESS MARKET CAP CATEGORIES
Classify cryptocurrencies by market cap: large caps (lower risk/reward), midcaps (moderate risk/reward), small caps and meme coins (high risk/reward).

STEP 3: BUILD BALANCED PORTFOLIO
Create diversified portfolio across large, mid, and small cap cryptocurrencies to manage overall portfolio risk while maintaining growth potential.

STEP 4: SELECT TRADING PLATFORM
Choose reputable cryptocurrency exchange (e.g., Bybit) that provides comprehensive market data, charting tools, and order execution capabilities.

STEP 5: IDENTIFY MARKET DIRECTION
Start analysis on 4-hour or 1-hour timeframe, draw market structure schematic from lowest to highest swings to determine current market control.

STEP 6: CONFIRM DIRECTIONAL BIAS
In bullish market, confirm price respects demand areas making higher highs/lows; in bearish market, confirm price respects supply making lower lows/highs.

STEP 7: ZOOM TO HIGHER TIMEFRAMES
Identify key levels on weekly, daily, and 4-hour timeframes using criteria: multiple touches, long rejection wicks, drastic moves with imbalance.

STEP 8: ASSESS AVAILABLE SPACE
Determine how much room price has before reaching next major key level to gauge trade potential and set realistic targets.

STEP 9: WAIT FOR RETRACEMENT
Once impulsive move aligned with direction identified, wait for price to retrace back toward 61.8%-78.6% Fibonacci retracement zone.

STEP 10: SET ENTRY PARAMETERS
Place buy order in middle of optimal Fibonacci zone, set stop loss below swing low, target first key level in front of price.

STEP 11: SEEK LOWER TIMEFRAME CONFIRMATION
Optionally zoom to lower timeframes for additional confirmation signals such as double bottom or demand zone reaction within optimal entry zone.

STEP 12: EXECUTE WITH RISK MANAGEMENT
Enter trade with predetermined position size based on account risk percentage, never risk more than account can afford to lose per trade.

STEP 13: BACKTEST STRATEGY THOROUGHLY
Before live trading, conduct extensive backtesting to build confidence, assess win rate, maximum drawdown, and overall performance metrics.

STEP 14: JOURNAL AND REVIEW TRADES
Maintain detailed trading journal documenting all entries, exits, reasoning, and outcomes to identify patterns and continuously improve strategy.

================================================================================
TRADING CHECKLISTS
================================================================================

A. MARKET ANALYSIS & DIRECTION IDENTIFICATION

- [ ] Selected 4-hour or 1-hour chart as base timeframe for analysis
- [ ] Drew market structure schematic from lowest to highest visible swings
- [ ] Identified recent movements of bulls and bears for control assessment
- [ ] Confirmed bullish market making higher highs and higher lows OR bearish market making lower lows and lower highs
- [ ] Verified price respecting demand areas (bullish) or supply areas (bearish)
- [ ] Checked for any break of structure indicating potential trend change
- [ ] Noted any consolidation or ranging periods within current structure
- [ ] Assessed current market sentiment and directional momentum
- [ ] Determined if market in trending or ranging state
- [ ] Confirmed market direction aligns with higher timeframe bias

B. HIGHER TIMEFRAME KEY LEVEL IDENTIFICATION

- [ ] Zoomed out to weekly timeframe to identify major structural levels
- [ ] Marked daily timeframe key levels near current price action
- [ ] Identified 4-hour timeframe key levels for refined precision
- [ ] Verified key levels have multiple touches indicating trader attention
- [ ] Confirmed long rejection wicks showing immediate price rejection
- [ ] Identified drastic moves away with imbalance suggesting institutional participation
- [ ] Assessed available space between current price and next key level
- [ ] Determined realistic profit targets based on next key level location
- [ ] Noted support/resistance flip levels that have acted as both
- [ ] Adjusted level boundaries based on candlestick bodies and wicks

C. FIBONACCI RETRACEMENT ENTRY SETUP

- [ ] Identified latest impulsive move aligned with market direction
- [ ] Applied Fibonacci retracement tool from start of impulsive move to end
- [ ] Marked optimal entry zone between 61.8% and 78.6% Fibonacci levels
- [ ] Confirmed optimal zone aligns with demand area (bullish) or supply area (bearish)
- [ ] Waited for price to retrace into optimal Fibonacci entry zone
- [ ] Checked for additional confluence factors at entry zone
- [ ] Prepared buy/sell order parameters for execution
- [ ] Zoomed to lower timeframe for refined entry confirmation (optional)
- [ ] Looked for double bottom (bullish) or double top (bearish) inside zone
- [ ] Verified no major key levels blocking path to profit target

D. TRADE EXECUTION & RISK MANAGEMENT

- [ ] Calculated position size based on predetermined account risk percentage
- [ ] Set stop loss below swing low (bullish) or above swing high (bearish)
- [ ] Determined stop loss distance in pips/ticks for R:R calculation
- [ ] Identified first key level in front of price as initial profit target
- [ ] Calculated risk-to-reward ratio ensuring minimum 1:2 or better
- [ ] Placed entry order at optimal price within Fibonacci zone
- [ ] Confirmed order parameters correct before execution
- [ ] Documented trade setup, reasoning, and parameters in trading journal
- [ ] Set alerts for price reaching entry zone or stop loss level
- [ ] Maintained emotional discipline to follow plan without deviation
- [ ] Prepared to trail stop loss if price moves favorably toward target
- [ ] Reviewed portfolio balance ensuring diversification across market caps

• Turning to second method for executing trades when price accelerates without pullback

• First step involves identifying breakout of key level structure on chart
• Breakout typically signaled by engulfing candle where price breaks key area with momentum

• Candle pattern engulfs previous candles signaling significant move in market
• Strategy can be applied across various timeframes but most effective on higher frames
• Clarity and reliability of signals tend to be higher on longer timeframes
• Higher timeframe advantage: cleaner breakout patterns with stronger institutional participation

• Know exactly where looking and what criteria need to consider
• However strategy also comes with notable drawbacks to acknowledge
• May sometimes experience fakeouts when false breakouts occur
• Entry method involves larger stop-loss area due to pattern requirements
• Larger stop area provides lower reward to risk ratio compared to tight stop trades
• Drawback makes position sizing critical to overall trading success

**[5:42] - [6:27] | Candlestick Pattern Requirements for Entry**

• Specific candlestick pattern wanted near supply zone for entry confirmation
• First element: Initial candle that pushes into point of interest zone
• Second element: Price starts to react to zone showing rejection from it
• Rejection can occur with single candle or multiple candles at zone
• Third element: Engulfing candle breaks out of supply zone engulfing reaction candles
• Pattern doesn't always occur within three-candle sequence as shown
• Can happen within more candles representing extended reaction/rejection phase
• Looking for last candle engulfing reaction candles breaking out supply zone
• Waiting for price break below bodies and also wicks of reaction candles
• Specific pattern formation validates candle breakout strategy execution

ICT Mapping:
- **Three Phase Pattern**: Mitigation → Rejection → Breakout = ICT's institutional process
- **Initial Candle**: Pushes into OB = smart money testing zone validity
- **Rejection Phase**: Shows resistance = institutional rejection confirmation
- **Engulfing Candle**: Breakout confirmation = clean BOS with institutional participation
- **Wick Below**: Price goes below wicks = full zone mitigation verification

**[7:27] - [8:05] | Three Candle Sequence Not Always Required**

• Crucial noting that pattern doesn't always occur three candle sequence
• Main focus on identifying engulfing candle breaking out point of interest zone
• Engulfing candle must aggressively engulf previous reaction candle body and wick
• Not limited to three-candle pattern; can take more or fewer candles
• Flexibility within pattern allows adaptation to different market conditions
• Key is recognizing final engulfing candle that completes pattern regardless sequence length
• Another crucial point: look for pattern forming at unmitigated point of interest
• Not at random chart places or previously mitigated key levels
• Restricting pattern search to unmitigated zones critical to strategy success
• Mitigated levels already swept of liquidity reducing probability potential

ICT Mapping:
- **Pattern Flexibility**: Sequence length varies = market structure adaptation required
- **Final Engulfing**: Regardless length, engulfing candle = BOS confirmation signal
- **Aggressive Engulfing**: Body + wick penetration = full institutional conviction
- **Unmitigated Requirement**: Fresh zones = higher probability institutional positioning
- **Mitigation History**: Swept levels = lower probability due liquidity already taken

- **Short Opportunity**: Mitigation of OB = high probability reversal entry zone
- **Momentum Observation**: Strong push = institutional buyer participation exhaustion tracking

(165 words) ✓

• Eventually price forms engulfing candle breaking below order block
• Engulfing candle engulfs previous reaction candles below zone
• Going enter sell order close engulfing candle level
• Stop loss set above engulfing candle managing upside risk exposure
• Take-profit targeting nearest swing low as first target zone
• Subsequent lower swing low as second target level ahead
• Price descending reaching first take-profit target successfully
• Trade continues descending reaching second take-profit target
• Both take-profit targets reached confirming trade thesis again
• Great see both targets hit showing strategy effectiveness

ICT Mapping:
- **Engulfing Below**: Breaking below OB = institutional seller participation confirmation
- **Engulfing Reaction**: Engulfs candles = full institutional short conviction
- **Stop Above**: Managing upside risk = protecting against liquidity grabs above
- **First Target**: Nearest swing low = institutional support/demand zone ahead
- **Second Target**: Lower swing low = extended institutional weakness continuation
